<title>Tips to Speed Up Your Mac</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/tips-to-speed-up-your-mac/</link>
<pubDate>Sun, 28 Jun 2009 12:06:54 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mac]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mac"><![CDATA[Mac]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[OS X]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="os-x"><![CDATA[OS X]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[OSX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="osx"><![CDATA[OSX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Tips]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="tips"><![CDATA[Tips]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=39</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/3249C295-D84A-45FE-AE48-40169547FF0A.jpg" alt="3249C295-D84A-45FE-AE48-40169547FF0A.jpg" border="0" width="400" height="400" align="center" />

Sometimes, but only sometimes, you may need to take some steps to help the performance of you mac

Here are some tips to help you:


<strong>1. Do a widget inventory</strong>

Widgets are easy to forget and id your having a slow day you may add a few more than necessary !

But leave them all running and they may hog some of your systems resources.

Show no mercy and remove the ones you don't really need !


<strong>2. Declutter your desktop.</strong>

Only for pre-leopard users, but OSX treats each icon as its own window, thus hogging resources.  A few icons won't do too much harm but if you desktop looks like a plate of beans, it may be time to do some tidying...


<strong>3. Keep an eye on the Activity Monitor.</strong>

In Applications/Utilities there us a great little program called Activity Monitor (or great big one depending on your point of view)

Open it and see exactly what is using your system resources...

You may be surprised!


<strong>4. Turn off unused features. </strong>

Did you use Bluetooth the other day..?  Did you turn it off again?

Check your System Preferences to make sure everything your not using is turned off ! !


<strong>5. Delete unused preference panes.</strong>

Sometimes software you install puts a pane in your System Preferences.  If your not using it, again remove it.

Do you have any more tips, let us know !]]></content:encoded>

<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[An interesting list of 13 Free Mac OS X apps from SmashingApps

<a href="http://www.smashingapps.com/2009/05/19/11-free-mac-os-x-apps-that-you-probably-want-to-try.html">13 Free Mac OS X Apps That You Probably Want To Try</a>


<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/90DB3437-4FD5-4161-AB22-27D194955AC2.jpg" alt="90DB3437-4FD5-4161-AB22-27D194955AC2.jpg" border="0" width="400"  align="right" />

I tried and have kept <a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/applejack">AppleJack</a>

"AppleJack is a user friendly troubleshooting assistant for Mac OS X. With AppleJack you can troubleshoot a computer even if you can`t load the GUI, or don`t have a startup CD handy. AppleJack runs in Single User Mode and is menu-based for ease of use."



and...

<a href="http://danauclair.com/addressbooksync/">AddressBook Sync</a>

"AddressBookSync is a free Mac OS X application to download profile pictures and other Facebook data to Address Book cards. This is a handy tool to keep your contactsâ€™ pictures updated if you have numerous Facebook friends in your Mac OS X Address Book."

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/22886B96-F582-46DE-90D9-FF0D3EFFA364.jpg" alt="22886B96-F582-46DE-90D9-FF0D3EFFA364.jpg" border="0" width="400"  /></div>

Let me know of anything else better !]]></content:encoded>

<title>Yahoo Working on Major Brand Overhaul</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/yahoo-working-on-major-brand-overhaul/</link>
<pubDate>Mon, 29 Jun 2009 17:55:09 +0000</pubDate>

<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/A7899663-6661-4CDF-A9EF-C1412D883175.jpg" alt="A7899663-6661-4CDF-A9EF-C1412D883175.jpg" border="0" width="200" height="50" align="left" />

Apparently Yahoo is working on a <a href="http://kara.allthingsd.com/20090624/exclusive-yahoo-working-on-major-brand-overhaul-please-no-more-yodeling/">major brand overhaul</a>

Considering these figures:

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/CFFEEB2D-28DE-40A9-8E96-0C4F9F34BB0F.jpg" alt="CFFEEB2D-28DE-40A9-8E96-0C4F9F34BB0F.jpg" border="0" width="450" /></div>

You gotta say it's gonna take more than a new logo...

<content:encoded><![CDATA[Typing !! followed by Enter will bring back and execute the last command (same as Ctrl+P followed by Enter).

<a href="http://tuxarena.blogspot.com/2009/06/6-bash-productivity-tips.html">From</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>Five Best Free System Restore Tools</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/five-best-free-system-restore-tools/</link>
<pubDate>Tue, 30 Jun 2009 08:57:00 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="hardware"><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Backup]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="backup"><![CDATA[Backup]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=75</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[As listed by <a href="http://lifehacker.com/5303067/five-best-free-system-restore-tools">lifehacker.com</a>

Backing up data is a great way to minimize losses after a computing catastrophe. But what about restoring your actual system right away?


<strong><a href="http://www.macrium.com/reflectfree.asp">Macrium Reflect Free</a> (Windows, Free)</strong>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/C7EF4F40-1639-4D75-943B-61F092F811E0.jpg" alt="C7EF4F40-1639-4D75-943B-61F092F811E0.jpg" border="0" width="450"  /></div>

Macrium Reflect Free is a no-cost but capable version of the popular Macrium Reflect disk imaging tool. With it you can back up your disk to network locations, optical and removable media, and other hard drives

<strong><a href="http://www.runtime.org/driveimage-xml.htm">DriveImageXML</a> (Windows, Free)</strong>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/A2F44AA4-B89F-4ABD-A97D-FF30CB0660B8.jpg" alt="A2F44AA4-B89F-4ABD-A97D-FF30CB0660B8.jpg" border="0" width="450"  /></div>

DriveImageXML creates thorough hard disk images, copies them from disk to disk, and offers browsing of backed-up disk images just like regular directories. That means if there are just a few files to grab from a previous image, there's no need for whole-cloth restorations, just a quick point-and-grab operation.

<strong><a href="http://www.paragon-software.com/home/db-express/features.html">Paragon Drive Backup Free</a> (Windows, Free)</strong>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/B1F6497C-3F37-4E2F-8FEF-1BF5632C8E86.jpg" alt="B1F6497C-3F37-4E2F-8FEF-1BF5632C8E86.jpg" border="0" width="450"  /></div>

Paragon Drive Backup is the free personal edition of Paragon's commercial disk imaging software, but supports a wider variety of disks and file systems than comparable backup tools. Paragon supports Microsoft Volume Shadow Services for real-time backup, and it can restore multiple partitions and disks in one shot following colossal hard drive failure.

<strong><a href="http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc722145(WS.10).aspx">ImageX</a> (Windows, Free)</strong>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/04379B72-6C18-49CC-B47D-1FDEE7FDFFC4.jpg" alt="04379B72-6C18-49CC-B47D-1FDEE7FDFFC4.jpg" border="0" width="450"  /></div>

ImageX was created as a tool for computer manufacturers and other large organizations with a need for imaging and deploying large numbers of computers. So it's primarily a command line tool, but because of its popularity with imaging geeks, a GUI, GImageX, was created for it seen in the screenshot here. Despite having several key limitations, most notably that it only works with modern Windows file systems, ImageX has quite a few excellent features if you're already rocking a Windows-centric house.


<a href="http://clonezilla.org/"><strong>Clonezilla</a> (Windows/Mac/Linux, Free)</strong>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/8B7FAD40-DE6D-4784-A349-1AA26174B68A.jpg" alt="8B7FAD40-DE6D-4784-A349-1AA26174B68A.jpg" border="0" width="450"  /></div>

Clonezilla is a powerful open-source disk imaging tool easy enough for new users to jump into. The deep-down features, though, may keep users around as their needs grow. The server edition allows for network-based bulk disk imaging, and Clonezilla itself supports over a half-dozen file systems covering Windows, Linux, and Mac-based machines. Even if you're using an obscure file system that isn't supported, you can still use Clonezilla, but you'll need to do a sector-to-sector copy instead of taking advantage of the efficiency and compression it applies when backing up a supported file system. The personal version of Clonezilla is a Live CD and customizable by the end user to meet a variety of needs in a variety of situations, with more than adequate documentation on the Clonezilla site to help you do so.


My vote goes with Clonezilla - open-source multi-platform has to win...!]]></content:encoded>
<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/69EDE262-871E-4F1A-8383-B2383C9E8EF8.jpg</guid>

<wp:post_id>82</wp:post_id>
<wp:post_date>2009-06-30 12:35:26</wp:post_date>
<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-06-30 11:35:26</wp:post_date_gmt>

<item>
<title>Five Apps for Diagnosing PC Problems!</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/five-apps-for-diagnosing-pc-problems/</link>
<pubDate>Tue, 30 Jun 2009 11:36:37 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=84</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/article/features/freeware_files_five_apps_diagnosing_pc_problems_341">Maximum PC</a> today gives us five apps for diagnosing a PC problem.

<blockquote>Applications that assess the health of your system's various parts serve a twofold purpose. You can deduce that equipment on your system might be going kaput or is otherwise screwed up in some fashion. Armed with that knowledge, you can then attempt to make an effective repair. If there is no way to repair your parts, you'll at least get an advanced notice that disaster is about to strike and that a trip to the electronics store might be in your soon-to-immediate future.</blockquote>

<a href="http://www.alcpu.com/CoreTemp/"><strong>Core Temp</strong></a>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/FD707ECD-B3D2-494E-9074-33434BDA1050.jpg" alt="FD707ECD-B3D2-494E-9074-33434BDA1050.jpg" border="0" width="328" height="335" /></div>

Core Temp is a quick and easy way to check out the temperature of your CPU as determined by the processor's internal probes.

Core Temp gets the reading right the first time, every time--a perfect tool for novice.

<a href="http://www.nutsaboutnets.com/performance-wifi/products/netstress-network-benchmarking.htm"><strong>NetStress</strong></a>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/C3675F30-916E-445A-A9E7-9152DFDA94BB.jpg" alt="C3675F30-916E-445A-A9E7-9152DFDA94BB.jpg" border="0" width="415" height="436" /></div>

NetStress is an offline tool that will help you isolate network peculiarities within your internal setup.  To gain the most use out of the program, set up your network and run the throughput benchmarking features at a time when you feel your setup is at peak efficiency. Record the numbers. Later, if you start to detect slowdowns or other strange goings-on, re-run the benchmarking application and see how your numbers stack up.

<a href="http://www.softpedia.com/get/CD-DVD-Tools/CD-DVD-Rip-Other-Tools/Nero-CDDVD-Speed.shtml"><strong>Nero DiscSpeed</strong></a>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/CBAB2314-B03D-4694-800C-58B1D3D01608.jpg" alt="CBAB2314-B03D-4694-800C-58B1D3D01608.jpg" border="0" width="415" height="339" /></div>

Although this program is no longer being updated in favor of a new paid-for application (grr), it's still a great way to analyze your drive's read and write speeds. For example, it's one of the best ways to figure out if your 52X burner is actually performing at 40X for some unknown reason--measurements like that aren't really the kind of thing that an average user can estimate by how the reading or writing process "feels." Get the real seek times, transfer rates, and other measurements with this helpful application.

<a href="http://hddscan.com/"><strong>HDDScan</strong></a>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/69EDE262-871E-4F1A-8383-B2383C9E8EF8.jpg" alt="69EDE262-871E-4F1A-8383-B2383C9E8EF8.jpg" border="0" width="415" height="281" /></div>

Pull up the drive's S.M.A.R.T. diagnostic information if you're just interested in a quick scan. If any statistic looks out-of-place or otherwise dangerous, the program will alert you via colored icons on the side of each piece of information. From there, you can conduct more thorough evaluations by using the application to run offline S.M.A.R.T. testing of any drive in your system, even those connected to your PC via USB or FireWire.


<a href="http://www.memtest86.com/"><strong>Memtest86</strong></a>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/E974D805-3811-4631-912C-5A8DA7903636.jpg" alt="E974D805-3811-4631-912C-5A8DA7903636.jpg" border="0" width="415" height="261" /></div>

It's an oldie, but a goodie. I have yet to find a more thorough or easier-to-use method for evaluating the health of your system's memory. Even Maximum PC itself agrees with me on this one. In fact, it's well worth your time to click that link and read about how you can use Memtest86 to your greatest advantage. If you're experience blue screens that have seemingly come out of nowhere and they match the qualifications of a typical memory issue (either the PFN_LIST_CORRUPT or PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA error messages), run Memtest86 as soon as you can to help you pinpoint the problem.

]]></content:encoded>

<title>Microsoft charges UK customers double for Windows 7</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/microsoft-charges-uk-customers-double-for-windows-7/</link>
<pubDate>Tue, 30 Jun 2009 15:16:42 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Windows]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Windows 7]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="windows-7"><![CDATA[Windows 7]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=87</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.macworld.co.uk/business/news/index.cfm?RSS&NewsID=26434">From todays Macworld</a>

Microsoft prices new OS at 41 per cent to 100 per cent more than in the US, but leaves out browser

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/2813BB05-6B9E-4AC4-9CB6-446F56D6653E.jpg" alt="2813BB05-6B9E-4AC4-9CB6-446F56D6653E.jpg" border="0" width="257" height="69" /></div>

<blockquote>European customers will pay up to twice as much for Windows 7 compared to US users, even though the new operating system will ship without a browser in Europe, according to Microsoft.

When the company launches Windows 7 on 22 October, it will price Windows 7 Home Premium, likely the most popular of the three editions available at retail, at â‚¬119.99 in the European Union (EU) and charge Â£79.99 in the UK. Those prices are the equivalent to $168.66 and $132.14., respectively, at Saturday's exchange rates. </blockquote>

Wow, thanks a bunch Microsoft, just another reason not to like you very much.....

<item>
<title>Intel launching cheaper SSDs with up to 320GB capacity in two weeks?</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/intel-launching-cheaper-ssds-with-up-to-320gb-capacity-in-two-weeks/</link>
<pubDate>Tue, 30 Jun 2009 15:19:03 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="hardware"><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=90</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/06/29/intel-launching-cheaper-ssds-with-up-to-320gb-capacity-soon/">From Engadget.com</a>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/AD552529-62FA-44AB-A264-67860848582D.jpg" alt="AD552529-62FA-44AB-A264-67860848582D.jpg" border="0" width="475" height="117" /></div>

Rumor has it that Intel is prepped to launch its new SSDs in the next two weeks. According to sources speaking to the The Inquirer, the new solid state disks will feature that smaller 34nm NAND Flash developed by Intel and Micron. As usual, the smaller manufacturing processes should allow for higher density SSDs (as high as 320GB) at a reduced cost to manufacture. In fact, INQ says, "there will be drives big enough to replace the HDDs in most, if not all laptops." With Intel already cutting SSD prices we remain optimistic that this rumor is true.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>8853192D-CD7E-466A-BE15-15FE5045DCEB.jpg</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/?attachment_id=94</link>
<pubDate>Tue, 30 Jun 2009 15:24:06 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/8853192D-CD7E-466A-BE15-15FE5045DCEB.jpg</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>YouTube uploads soar by 400 percent thanks to iPhone 3GS</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/youtube-uploads-soar-by-400-percent-thanks-to-iphone-3gs/</link>
<pubDate>Tue, 30 Jun 2009 15:25:21 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iphone"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=95</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/8853192D-CD7E-466A-BE15-15FE5045DCEB.jpg" alt="8853192D-CD7E-466A-BE15-15FE5045DCEB.jpg" border="0" width="200" height="255" align="left" />

Video sharing Web site YouTube has reported that mobile uploads to the video-sharing site have increased by 400 per cent since the iPhone 3GS was launched earlier this month.

YouTube also revealed that in the last six months, video uploads from mobile phones increased by 1,700 percent. The website said it thought new handsets and improvements to the site were responsible for the huge jump in uploads. 

<a href="http://www.macworld.co.uk/ipod-itunes/news/index.cfm?RSS&NewsID=26436">Source</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>Which Windows 7 Edition is Right for You ?</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/which-windows-7-edition-is-right-for-you/</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 01 Jul 2009 18:47:06 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Software Release]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="software-release"><![CDATA[Software Release]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Windows]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="windows"><![CDATA[Windows]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Windows 7]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="windows-7"><![CDATA[Windows 7]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=102</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/60740D1A-D2C7-4B85-8D69-9C194BDA4DD3.jpg" alt="60740D1A-D2C7-4B85-8D69-9C194BDA4DD3.jpg" border="0" width="350" height="288" /></div>

Windows 7 is almost upon us (unless you have the Release Candidate already)

But which one is right for you

Luckily unlike Vista there are only 3 version, <strong>Home</strong>, <strong>Professional</strong> and <strong>Ultimate</strong> !

There is a good article at <a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/article/%5Bprimary-term%5D/windows_7_feature_focus_which_windows_7_edition_right_you">maximumpc.com</a> that explains some of the differences

To sum it up though

<strong>Home</strong> has image backup as a core feature and is supposed to be a simple no brainer offering

<strong>Professional</strong> extra goodies are Windows XP Mode, Automatic backup supports network shares as well as local hard disks, Domain network support

<strong>Ultimate</strong> has everything else the others have plus Spport for BitLocker full-disk encryption and the ability to switch between languages on the fly

Personally I'm not sure that the differences are all that much to write home about

And it all seems a bit of a bother, why can't there by just one version that gives everybody the option to use whatever features they like or need

OS X anybody.....
]]></content:encoded>

<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jul 2009 15:29:44 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="hardware"><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/7B25F514-2DA8-4829-9667-87E58B0B6BB3.jpg" alt="7B25F514-2DA8-4829-9667-87E58B0B6BB3.jpg" border="0" width="450" height="380" /></div>

This device is launching exclusively at Borders UK who are also launching a download store .

If you get the 4GB expansion card there's room for a whopping 8000 books!

The price of Â£189 might seem a bit steep, but this also includes 100 free ebooks.  Not too bad....

<title>VirtualBox 3.0 Released</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/virtualbox-3-0-released/</link>
<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jul 2009 15:40:05 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Software Release]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="software-release"><![CDATA[Software Release]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Virtualbox]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="virtualbox"><![CDATA[Virtualbox]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Virtualisation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="virtualisation"><![CDATA[Virtualisation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Virtualization]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="virtualization"><![CDATA[Virtualization]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=130</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div style="text-align:left;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/691BD5E1-A13D-478E-8626-077CCFAE1D50.jpg" alt="691BD5E1-A13D-478E-8626-077CCFAE1D50.jpg" border="0" width="140" height="180" /></div>

VirtualBox 3 has been released

This fantastic free software is a great alternative for those with pockets not deep enough for the more expensive competition

This version offers up to 32 virtual CPU's and for Windows guests the ability to use Direct3D 8/9 applications / games

Virtualisation is great fun and very useful for software / web developers

<a href="http://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Changelog">Get yours here:</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>Swedenâ€™s Global Gaming to buy The Pirate Bay</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/sweden%e2%80%99s-global-gaming-to-buy-the-pirate-bay/</link>
<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jul 2009 19:12:49 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Downloads]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="downloads"><![CDATA[Downloads]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[File Sharing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="file-sharing"><![CDATA[File Sharing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Gaming]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="gaming"><![CDATA[Gaming]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Media]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="media"><![CDATA[Media]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Pirate Bay]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="pirate-bay"><![CDATA[Pirate Bay]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=133</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[Global Gaming Factory, a Swedish software company, on Tuesday said it had agreed a $7.7m deal to buy The Pirate Bay, the free file-sharing website at the centre of a notorious court case. <div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/35242395-078C-43BC-887E-E29576253E33.jpg" alt="35242395-078C-43BC-887E-E29576253E33.jpg" border="0" width="185" height="26" /></div>

<blockquote>The listed software company, Global Gaming Factory X AB (publ) (GGF) acquires The Pirate Bay website, http://www.thepiratebay.org, one of the 100 most visited websites in the world and the technology company Peerialism, that has developed next generation file-sharing technology. Following the completion of the acquisitions, GGF intends to launch new business models that allow compensation to the content providers and copyright owners. The responsibility for, and operation of the site will be taken over by GGF in connection with closing of the transaction, which is scheduled for August 2009.

"We would like to introduce models which entail that content providers and copyright owners get paid for content that is downloaded via the site" said Hans Pandeya, CEO GGF.

"The Pirate Bay is a site that is among the top 100 most visited Internet sites in the world. However, in order to live on, The Pirate Bay requires a new business model, which satisfies the requirements and needs of all parties, content providers, broadband operators, end users, and the judiciary. Content creators and providers need to control their content and get paid for it. File sharers' need faster downloads and better quality" continues Hans Pandeya.</blockquote>


<a href="http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/3c2622d8-6558-11de-8e34-00144feabdc0.html">Source</a>]]></content:encoded>

<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/Neuromancer.jpg" alt="Neuromancer.jpg" border="0" width="170" height="269" align="left" /> I can't believe this great book is 25 years old

I've not read it for while so I'm off to fish it off the book shelf

If you've never read it get it<a href="http://www.amazon.co.uk/Neuromancer-William-Gibson/dp/0006480411/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1246564586&sr=8-1"> here</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>What&#039;s the Best OS for Your Netbook?</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/whats-the-best-os-for-your-netbook/</link>
<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jul 2009 10:59:53 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="hardware"><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Linux]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="linux"><![CDATA[Linux]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Netbook]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="netbook"><![CDATA[Netbook]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Netbooks]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="netbooks"><![CDATA[Netbooks]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[OS]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="os"><![CDATA[OS]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Windows]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="windows"><![CDATA[Windows]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Windows 7]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="windows-7"><![CDATA[Windows 7]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[XP]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="xp"><![CDATA[XP]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=145</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/668D5323-894D-472C-BED4-79AA10E1471E.jpg" alt="668D5323-894D-472C-BED4-79AA10E1471E.jpg" border="0" width="415" height="281" /></div>

<a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/article/features/windows_7_vs_linux_whats_best_os_your_netbook">Maximum PC</a> has an informative article about which OS to use on your netbook

As they say

<blockquote>"That shiny new netbook is light and portable, plays music and movies, and cost less than an iPhone (with service). Problem is: you might be ready to chuck it off a bridge. Running the Intel Atom processor at only 1.60GHz, netbooks are a bit on the clunky side when it comes to actual data processing. No one is going to play World of Warcraft on one of these thin machines, but it sure would be great if OpenOffice, a music player, and Mozilla Firefox could run a little faster."</blockquote>

There conclusions though are a bit unconclusive!

<strong>Windows XP</strong>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/0124BF6A-E482-4C4A-A580-F55C60EA6B4B.jpg" alt="0124BF6A-E482-4C4A-A580-F55C60EA6B4B.jpg" border="0" width="415" height="243" /></div>

<blockquote>"We ended up viewing Windows XP as a â€œlive with it, not like itâ€ OS for netbooks, something you use if you can't stand any of the other more updated OSes, such as Ubuntu or Moblin. It's just not that exciting to think you will go back in time and use an OS that has worn out its welcome."</blockquote>


<strong>Windows 7</strong>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/A996A5E0-4CB9-4D2D-A4F1-504D7041EB78.jpg" alt="A996A5E0-4CB9-4D2D-A4F1-504D7041EB78.jpg" border="0" width="415" height="243" /></div>

<blockquote>"We didn't really expect Windows 7 to run fast on the Aspire One, but Microsoft may still surprise everyone and release a stripped-down version that runs faster on netbooks. In the end, we were not impressed with the boot time, long install process, and sluggish behavior with multiple apps running."</blockquote>

<strong>Ubuntu for Netbooks Remix</strong>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/9C50EBCD-00D9-463E-97D9-0B7FC384106B.jpg" alt="9C50EBCD-00D9-463E-97D9-0B7FC384106B.jpg" border="0" width="415" height="243" /></div>

<blockquote>"We picked Ubuntu for Netbooks Remix because it runs the fastest with multiple apps open, had some of the best UI features (such as a main screen intended for those unfamiliar with Linux), loaded and booted quickly, and just looks the best compared to all of the other OSes."</blockquote>


<strong>Moblin</strong>
<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/52961471-54CB-40B4-9A8D-C514EF606DA3.jpg" alt="52961471-54CB-40B4-9A8D-C514EF606DA3.jpg" border="0" width="415" height="243" /></div>
<blockquote>
"We're big fans of Moblin, it just needs work before it is ready to take up disk space as our netbook OS of choice. Ubuntu for Netbooks has the leg up here, but we do prefer the Moblin look and feel, quick access to Twitter, and the fact that it runs reasonably fast (with occasional stall-outs)."</blockquote>

<strong>Slax</strong>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/F39C1453-407B-41B3-B57D-1438F5A793E5.jpg" alt="F39C1453-407B-41B3-B57D-1438F5A793E5.jpg" border="0" width="415" height="243" /></div>

<blockquote>"So, if Slax performed so well in our tests, you might wonder why we did not pick it as the best choice for netbooks. Speed is important, and a main goal was to make the Aspire One run faster. However, we just were not as impressed with the OS overall, especially in terms of customization options, software support, and options for how you install it. You might be able to find a USB install and get Slax running well on a netbook, but one criterion we had was that the download and install process be easy and the OS work well without a lot of tweaking, and Slax falls short."</blockquote>


The <a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/article/features/windows_7_vs_linux_whats_best_os_your_netbook">full article</a> give a lot more detail, but I think you can get the idea from their conclusions !

Personally I think I'll stick with my MacBook ! !
]]></content:encoded>

<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[l like this little gem.
Out of the box, fully charge the battery(light on left front edge of netbook will go from orange to green when fully charged). Next boot up and it will lead you quickly through windows XP installation. Then configure it with programs like you want it. Then enjoy. It is a great product and a steal at this price.]]></wp:comment_content>

<content:encoded><![CDATA[Rolling out across 20 UK-based Vue cinemas from 10 July, O2â€™s Asteroid Storm will allow seated cinema punters to control the on-screen movements of the Starship O2 â€“ a damaged spaceship requiring the audienceâ€™s help to steer it safely out of an asteroid belt.

The craftâ€™s movements are controlled by different areas of the audience putting its hands up, which is made possible by two ceiling-mounted cameras that use infra-red scanners to track hand movements.

Cool....

<item>
<title>Is you iPhone 3GS too hot to handle ?</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/is-you-iphone-3gs-too-hot-to-handle/</link>
<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jul 2009 19:15:39 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iphone"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[3GS]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="3gs"><![CDATA[3GS]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="apple"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="iphone"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[iPod]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="ipod"><![CDATA[iPod]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=151</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[Apple has posted a document titled  <a href="http://support.apple.com/kb/HT2101">Keeping iPhone 3G and iPhone 3GS within acceptable operating temperatures</a>

There has been a number of claims about 3GS's getting too hot !!

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/84CB6A97-E1F9-4F99-BBC9-7C04A88727E8.jpg" alt="84CB6A97-E1F9-4F99-BBC9-7C04A88727E8.jpg" border="0" width="320" height="480" /></div>

They recommend the following:

    <li>Leaving the device in a car on a hot day</li>
    <li>Leaving it in direct sunlight for extended amounts of time</li>
    <li>Using certain applications in hot conditions or direct sunlight for 		long periods of time, such as GPS tracking in a car on a sunny day 		or listening to music while in direct sunlight</li>

Hmmm not too difficult I'm sure....

]]></content:encoded>
<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<content:encoded><![CDATA[Rumours abound that Google will be releasing a OS (Operating System) very soon.

The OS will be aimed directly at netbooks and will be based around their Chrome web browser. 

]]></content:encoded>

<title>Paste without formatting by default is OSX</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/paste-without-formatting-by-default-is-osx/</link>
<pubDate>Thu, 09 Jul 2009 11:22:30 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Tips]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="tips"><![CDATA[Tips]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="apple"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Leopard]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="leopard"><![CDATA[Leopard]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[OS X]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="os-x"><![CDATA[OS X]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[OSX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="osx"><![CDATA[OSX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Tips]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="tips"><![CDATA[Tips]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=161</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[Great tip on <a href="http://www.tuaw.com/2009/07/07/tuaw-tip-paste-without-formatting-by-default/">The Unofficial Apple Weblog</a> today

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/063066F2-55FB-4A51-A0E3-A4825CA0EB39.jpg" alt="063066F2-55FB-4A51-A0E3-A4825CA0EB39.jpg" border="0" width="470" /></div>

Thanks to the Keyboard & Mouse pane in System Preferences. If you click the Keyboard Shortcuts tab, you can assign "Paste Without Formatting" and/or "Paste and Match Style" to Command + V for all applications. Just click the plus button under the list, type in the name of the appropriate menu items, and press âŒ˜-V in the Keyboard Shortcut box. 

Nice...]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>Talk Talk drops Phorm as well</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/talk-talk-drops-phorm-as-well/</link>
<pubDate>Thu, 09 Jul 2009 18:57:10 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Internet]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="internet"><![CDATA[Internet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Internet Service Providers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="internet-service-providers"><![CDATA[Internet Service Providers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[ISP]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="isp"><![CDATA[ISP]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Phorm]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="phorm"><![CDATA[Phorm]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Talk Talk]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="talk-talk"><![CDATA[Talk Talk]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=166</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[The <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/8140368.stm">BBC reports</a> today that Talk Talk is also dropping the Phorm service.

This follows news earlier in the week that BT had no immediate plans to use the service. 

Phorm has developed technology which collects information on web use in order to better target adverts but it has proved extremely controversial.

The loss of its key partners saw Phorm's shares tumble by more than 50%. 

<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/B435494A-B05D-47F5-A37F-9F204FAFCB81.jpg" alt="B435494A-B05D-47F5-A37F-9F204FAFCB81.jpg" border="0" width="226" height="170" align="right" />]]></content:encoded>
<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
<wp:post_id>166</wp:post_id>
<wp:post_date>2009-07-09 19:57:10</wp:post_date>
<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-07-09 18:57:10</wp:post_date_gmt>
<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

<item>
<title>Google Releasing Chrome Operating System - Finally!!</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/google-releasing-chrome-operating-system-finally/</link>
<pubDate>Thu, 09 Jul 2009 19:06:45 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[chrome]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="chrome"><![CDATA[chrome]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[google]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="google"><![CDATA[google]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Microsoft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="microsoft"><![CDATA[Microsoft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Netbooks]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="netbooks"><![CDATA[Netbooks]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[OS]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="os"><![CDATA[OS]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[PC]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="pc"><![CDATA[PC]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=171</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[Google have finally said it would release an open-source operating system based on its Chrome browser. The OS will be free, geared (at first) toward netbooks, and focused on "speed, simplicity, and security."

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/531DE9CD-484E-4228-8712-45C9B6E3DBF3.jpg" alt="531DE9CD-484E-4228-8712-45C9B6E3DBF3.jpg" border="0" width="360" height="340" /></div>


There have been rumours of this for a long long time ! !

It will be "Cloud-based" meaning that all of your files will reside in the cloud and probably called Chrome OS

Clearly this will be aimed and making the most of Google's online services like Google Docs.

The OS Wars are now officially back on, with the Google Chrome OS looking like a worthy contender to do battle with Mac and Windows.

Google's blog give some details of the basic aims of the OS.

<blockquote>"We're designing the OS to be fast and lightweight, to start up and get you onto the web in a few seconds. The user interface is minimal to stay out of your way, and most of the user experience takes place on the web. And as we did for the Google Chrome browser, we are going back to the basics and completely redesigning the underlying security architecture of the OS so that users don't have to deal with viruses, malware and security updates. It should just work."</blockquote>


<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/38E480DF-C4D1-4FB7-9B91-975B81E4F92C.jpg" alt="38E480DF-C4D1-4FB7-9B91-975B81E4F92C.jpg" border="0" width="470"  /></div>

This is clearly a direct challenge to market leader Microsoft and its Windows system.

Google Chrome OS will be aimed initially at small, low-cost netbooks, but will eventually be used on PCs as well.

Google said netbooks with Chrome OS could be on sale by the middle of 2010. 

]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>Wired&#039;s 100 Essential Skills for Geeks</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/wireds-100-essential-skills-for-geeks/</link>
<pubDate>Sat, 11 Jul 2009 11:53:02 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Funny]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="funny"><![CDATA[Funny]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Computers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="computers"><![CDATA[Computers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Geek]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="geek"><![CDATA[Geek]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Geeks]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="geeks"><![CDATA[Geeks]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=173</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<ol>
<li>Properly <a href="http://www.ehow.com/how_2253625_secure-wireless-router.html">secure</a> a wireless router.</li>
<li><a href="http://www.lifehacker.com.au/2009/07/how-to-crack-a-wi-fi-networks-wep-password-with-backtrack/">Crack</a> the WEP key on a wireless router.</li>
<li>Leech Wifi from your neighbor.</li>
<li>Screw with Wifi leeches.</li>
<li>Setup and <a href="http://www.itsatechworld.com/2006/01/29/how-to-configure-openvpn/">use a VPN</a>.</li>
<li>Work from home or a coffee shop as effectively as you do at the office.</li>
<li><a href="http://www.engadget.com/2006/08/22/how-to-run-your-own-network-wiring/">Wire your own</a> home with Ethernet cable.</li>
<li>Turn a web camera into <a href="http://lifehacker.com/203905/use-your-webcam-as-a-security-camera">security camera</a>.</li>
<li>Use your <a href="http://www.joiku.com/index.php?action=products&amp;mode=productDetails&amp;product_id=310">3G phone as a Wi-Fi</a> access point.</li>
<li>Understand what &#8220;There&#8217;s no Place Like <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Localhost">127.0.0.1</a>&#8221; means.</li>
<li>Identify key-loggers.</li>
<li>Properly connect a TV, Tivo, XBox, Wii, and Apple TV so they all work together with the one remote.</li>
<li>Program a universal remote.</li>
<li>Swap out the battery on your iPod/iPhone.</li>
<li>Benchmark Your Computer</li>
<li>Identify all computer components on sight.</li>
<li>Know which parts to order from NewEgg.com, and how to assemble them into a working PC.</li>
<li>Troubleshoot any computer/gadget problem, over the phone.</li>
<li>Use any piece of technology intuitively, without instruction or prior knowledge.</li>
<li>How to irrecoverably protect data.</li>
<li>Recover data from a dead hard drive.</li>
<li>Share a printer between a Mac and a PC on a network.</li>
<li>Install a Linux distribution. (Hint: <a href="http://www.ubuntu.com/GetUbuntu/download">Ubuntu 9.04</a> is easier than installing Windows)</li>
<li>Remove a virus from a computer.</li>
<li>Dual (or more) boot a computer.</li>
<li>Boot a computer off a thumb drive.</li>
<li>Boot a computer off a network drive.</li>
<li>Replace or repair a laptop keyboard.</li>
<li>Run <a href="http://www.codinghorror.com/blog/archives/000740.html">more than two monitors</a> on a single computer.</li>
<li>Successfully <a href="http://www.laptop-repair.info/take_laptop_apart.html">disassemble</a> and reassemble a laptop.</li>
<li>Know at least 10 software easter eggs off the top of your head.</li>
<li>Bypass a computer password on all major operating systems. <a href="http://wareseeker.com/Utilities/cia-commander-1.0.zip/401209">Windows</a>, <a href="http://support.apple.com/kb/HT1274?locale=us_US">Mac</a>, <a href="http://www.debuntu.org/recover-root-password-single-user-mode-and-grub">Linux</a></li>
<li>Carrying a computer cleaning arsenal on your USB drive.</li>
<li>Bypass content filters on public computers.</li>
<li>Protect your privacy when using a public computer.</li>
<li>Surf the web anonymously from home.</li>
<li>Buy a domain, configure bind, apache, MySQL, php, and Wordpress without Googling a how-to.</li>
<li>Basic *nix command shell knowledge with the ability to edit and save a file with vi.</li>
<li>Create a web site using vi.</li>
<li>Transcode a DVD to play on a portable device.</li>
<li>Hide a file in an image using <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steganography">steganography</a>.</li>
<li>Knowing the answer to life, the universe and everything.</li>
<li><a href="http://synergy2.sourceforge.net/">Share a single keyboard and mouse</a> between multiple computers without a KVM switch.</li>
<li>Google obscure facts in under 3 searches. Bonus point if you can use I Feel Lucky.</li>
<li>Build amazing structures with LEGO and invent a compelling back story for the creation.</li>
<li>Understand that it is LEGO, not Lego, Legos, or Lego&#8217;s.</li>
<li>Build a two story house out of LEGO, in monochrome, with a balcony.</li>
<li>Construct a costume for you or your kid out of scraps, duct tape, paper mÃ¢chÃ©, and imagination.</li>
<li>Be able to <a href="http://lifehacker.com/399735/how-to-pick-a-lock-with-a-bump-key">pick a lock</a>.</li>
<li>Determine the combination of a <a href="http://lifehacker.com/301018/crack-a-master-combination-padlock">Master combination padlock</a> in under 10 minutes.</li>
<li>Assemble IKEA furniture without looking at the instructions. Bonus point if you don&#8217;t have to backtrack.</li>
<li>Use a digital SLR in full manual mode.</li>
<li>Do cool things to Altoids tins.</li>
<li>Be able to construct <a href="http://www.papercrafty.com/2007/sci-fi-spaceship-papercraft-models">paper craft versions of space ships</a>.</li>
<li>Origami! Bonus point for duct tape origami. (<a href=" http://tr.im/Ductigami">Ductigami</a>)</li>
<li>Fix anything with duct tape, chewing gum and wire.</li>
<li>Knowing how to avoid being eaten by a grue.</li>
<li>Know what a grue is.</li>
<li>Understand where <a href="http://www.ifiction.org/games/play.phpz?cat=&amp;game=1&amp;mode=html">XYZZY</a> came from, and have used it.</li>
<li>Play any SNES game on your computer through an emulator.</li>
<li>Burn the rope.</li>
<li>Know the Konami code, and where to use it.</li>
<li>Whistle, hum, or play on an iPhone, the Cantina song.</li>
<li>Learning to play the theme songs to the kids favorite TV shows.</li>
<li>Solve a Rubik&#8217;s Cube.</li>
<li>Calculate THAC0.</li>
<li>Know the difference between skills and traits.</li>
<li>Explain special relativity in terms an eight-year-old can grasp.</li>
<li>Recite pi to 10 places or more.</li>
<li>Be able to calculate tip and split the check, all in your head.</li>
<li>Explain that the colours in a rainbow are roygbiv.</li>
<li>Understand the electromagnetic spectrum - xray, uv, visible, infrared, microwave, radio.</li>
<li>Know the difference between radiation and radioactive contamination.</li>
<li>Understand  basic electronics components like resistors, capacitors, inductors and transistors.</li>
<li>Solder a circuit while bottle feeding an infant. (lead free solder please.)</li>
<li>The meaning of technical acronyms.</li>
<li>The coffee dash, blindfolded (or blurry eyed). Coffee &lt;brew&gt; [cream] [sugar]. In under a minute.</li>
<li>Build a fighting robot.</li>
<li>Program a fighting robot.</li>
<li>Build a failsafe into a fighting robot so it doesn&#8217;t kill you.</li>
<li>Be able to trace the Fellowship&#8217;s journey on a map of Middle Earth.</li>
<li>Know all the names of the Dwarves in The Hobbit.</li>
<li>Understand the difference between a comic book and a graphic novel.</li>
<li>Know where your towel is and why it is important.</li>
<li>Re-enact the parrot sketch.</li>
<li>Know the words to The Lumberjack Song.</li>
<li>Reciting key scenes from Monty Python and the Holy Grail.</li>
<li>Be able to recite at least one Geek Movie word for word.</li>
<li>Know what the 8th Chevron does on a Stargate and how much power is required to get a lock.</li>
<li>Be able to explain why it&#8217;s important that Han shot first.</li>
<li>Know why it is just wrong for Luke and Leia to kiss.</li>
<li>Stop talking Star Wars long enough to get laid.</li>
<li>The ability to name actors, characters and plotlines from the majority of sci-fi movies produced since 1968.</li>
<li>Cite Mythbusters when debunking a myth or urban legend.</li>
<li>Sleep with a Cricket bat next to your bed.</li>
<li>Have a documented plan on what to do during a zombie or robot uprising.</li>
<li>Identify evil alternate universe versions of friends, family, co-workers or self.</li>
<li>Be able to convince TSA that the electronic parts you are carrying are really not a threat to passengers.</li>
<li>Talk about things that aren&#8217;t tech related.</li>
<li>Get something on the front page of Digg.</li>
</ol>

<a href="http://www.wired.com/geekdad/2009/07/100-basic-geek-skills-for-geeks/">Great list</a>, of course I can do all these....
]]></content:encoded>
<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<title>BBC News: Mobile broadband notspots mapped</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/bbc-news-mobile-broadband-notspots-mapped/</link>
<pubDate>Mon, 13 Jul 2009 19:20:45 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=176</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/8140947.stm">The BBC reports that:</a>

There are still significant notspots when it comes to 3G mobile coverage in the UK, regulator Ofcom has revealed.

It has pledged to investigate why some places, particularly in rural areas, are still failing to get any coverage. 

It also said it will investigate mobile broadband speeds, which vary tremendously in different areas and at different times of day.

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/0C32658F-4D7D-46FA-B9C1-8FD7814D7DE9.jpg" alt="0C32658F-4D7D-46FA-B9C1-8FD7814D7DE9.jpg" border="0" width="466" height="500" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>FT.com reports: LCD makers face cartel claim</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/ft-com-reports-lcd-makers-face-cartel-claim/</link>
<pubDate>Tue, 14 Jul 2009 20:58:05 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Displays]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="displays"><![CDATA[Displays]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[FT]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="ft"><![CDATA[FT]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[LCD]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="lcd"><![CDATA[LCD]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[LG]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="lg"><![CDATA[LG]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Phillips]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="phillips"><![CDATA[Phillips]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=178</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7a98c31c-700d-11de-b835-00144feabdc0.html">The FT reports:</a> 

Manufacturers of liquid crystal display panels have been charged by Europe's top competition regulator with running a cartel.

The European Commission did not identify the suspected cartel members, but Royal Philips, the Dutch electronics company,acknowledged that it had received the formal statement of objections in respect to LG Display, a jointly owned business in which it has since sold its remaining stake.

The Commission's charges - which were delivered to the companies two months ago but which came to light only yesterday - come three years after it was revealed that authorities in the US, Japan, South Korea and Europe had launched an international investigation into alleged price-fixing by LCD screen manufacturers.

<a href="http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7a98c31c-700d-11de-b835-00144feabdc0.html">Read More</a>]]></content:encoded>

<title>Is the iPhone screen scratch proof</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/is-the-iphone-screen-scratch-proof/</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 22 Jul 2009 13:52:58 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iphone"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="apple"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="hardware"><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="iphone"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mac]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mac"><![CDATA[Mac]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=185</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[So I've just taken delivery of some screen protectors for my new iPhone

After fiddling for ages I finally  get them fitted

However I cannot seem to get rid of all the bubbles, and even if I could it would still look pretty lame

So the thought occurred, (a thought that I should have had before my impulse buy of screen protectors!), just how tough is the iPhone screen?

So to Google....

and I found this:


<object width="425" height="344"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/m-sRbeBehNs&color1=0xb1b1b1&color2=0xcfcfcf&feature=player_embedded&fs=1"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/m-sRbeBehNs&color1=0xb1b1b1&color2=0xcfcfcf&feature=player_embedded&fs=1" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowfullscreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" width="425" height="344"></embed></object>


<a href="http://iphonescratches.com/">From here</a>

So I've thrown away my new screen protectors and will learn my lesson well!!

]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>O2 free Twitter updates live early</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/o2-free-twitter-updates-live-early/</link>
<pubDate>Thu, 30 Jul 2009 20:45:56 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="iphone"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mobile Broadband]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mobile-broadband"><![CDATA[Mobile Broadband]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mobiles]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mobiles"><![CDATA[Mobiles]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[O2]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="o2"><![CDATA[O2]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Twitter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="twitter"><![CDATA[Twitter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Updates]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="updates"><![CDATA[Updates]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=192</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[O2, the exclusive carrier for the Apple iPhone, has teamed up with Twitter to make its users tweets mobile. 

Previously it has stated that the service would go live in August. Now O2 has announced that it has got "everything ready early so weâ€™re making it available now!". 

<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/839A300B-2799-49AD-9467-BACBD9188005.jpg" alt="839A300B-2799-49AD-9467-BACBD9188005.jpg" border="0" width="224" height="55" align="right" />

O2's instructions for setting up Twitter messages on mobile devices:

"To set Twitter texts up, head to Twitter, choose Settings then Devices. Once you've followed the prompts there, you can then choose which followers you want to get texts from. You'll then receive each of their status updates by text message - you can also choose to receive every direct message you get too.

"From today you can also send Twitter updates to 86444 - texts to this number will cost your normal text message rate or be part of your inclusive bundle. We've put together a list of some questions and answers about how to use Twitter on your O2 mobile below. You can find more at Twitter's website."

It's free to receive Twitter updates by O2 text message. 

]]></content:encoded>

<title>Western Digital My Book Mac Edition 1TB</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/western-digital-my-book-mac-edition-1tb/</link>
<pubDate>Thu, 30 Jul 2009 21:19:38 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="hardware"><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Accessories]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="accessories"><![CDATA[Accessories]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[External Hardrive]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="external-hardrive"><![CDATA[External Hardrive]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mac]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mac"><![CDATA[Mac]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[USB Hardrive]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="usb-hardrive"><![CDATA[USB Hardrive]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Western Digital]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="western-digital"><![CDATA[Western Digital]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=195</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[The My Book Mac Edition is bulky but offers faster-than-expected USB connectivity.

The My Book Mac Edition is thick, about as wide and tall as a hardcover book. It

As the name implies, the My Book Mac Edition is designed for the Mac and is Time Machine-ready. The 1TB capacity in the unit I tested ensures that everyone, save professional video and audio editors, will have plenty of storage space for documents, files, and folders.

<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/B569EDF7-10B6-4DD0-9253-E7DA4692AD2B.jpg" alt="B569EDF7-10B6-4DD0-9253-E7DA4692AD2B.jpg" border="0" width="386" height="386" align="left" />]]></content:encoded>
<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/08/3BAEEA28-C42E-4322-A6C1-DD5075D01CDD.jpg" alt="3BAEEA28-C42E-4322-A6C1-DD5075D01CDD.jpg" border="0" width="200" height="150" align="right" /> So where are the best websites for buying computer parts in the UK ?

A quick look around the web reveals these sites:

<a href="http://www.novatech.co.uk/novatech/">Novatech</a>

<a href="http://www.scan.co.uk/">Scan.co.uk</a>

<a href="http://www.ebuyer.com/">ebuyer.com</a>

<a href="http://www.overclockers.co.uk/">Overclockers UK</a>

Unfortunately my old favourite <a href="http://www.komplett.co.uk/k/k.aspx">Komplett.co.uk</a> has ceased trading in the UK

Who do you use for your computer parts..?

<title>Microsoftâ€™s Windows 7 pricing in the UK - Scandal ?</title>

<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.pcpro.co.uk/blogs/2009/07/31/the-scandal-that-is-microsofts-windows-7-pricing-in-the-uk">PC Pro</a> has reported on some of the interesting Windows 7 pricing options that will be available in the UK

I can only agree with them when they say "Rip-off UK pricing doesnâ€™t even begin to cover it."

Here are the three key potential upgrades:

Windows 7 Home Premium â€“> Professional: Â£120 inc VAT

Windows 7 Home Premium â€“> Ultimate: Â£125 inc VAT

Windows 7 Professional â€“> Ultimate: Â£85 inc VAT

Compared to US pricing

Windows 7 Home Premium â€“> Professional: $90 (around Â£54)

Windows 7 Home Premium â€“> Ultimate: $140 (around Â£84)

Windows 7 Professional â€“> Ultimate: $130 (around Â£78)


<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/60740D1A-D2C7-4B85-8D69-9C194BDA4DD3.jpg" alt="60740D1A-D2C7-4B85-8D69-9C194BDA4DD3.jpg" border="0" width="350" height="288" align="right" />

And they go on:

"And then, just to rub our noses in it that bit more, we have the fact that UK users canâ€™t buy the Family Pack of Windows 7 due to the ridiculous mess that is the Windows E edition (in short: thereâ€™s no Internet Explorer built in to the EC editions of Windows 7, and Microsoft says that makes it technically impossible - right now - to upgrade direct from Vista)."

One can only say wow ! !

Personally I'm looking forward to the next OS X update (Snow Leopard) - one version, one price, not too tricky to work out which one I need ! ! !

<title>The Mac OS X 10.5.8 update is now available</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/the-mac-os-x-10-5-8-update-is-now-available/</link>
<pubDate>Thu, 06 Aug 2009 07:59:57 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="apple"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[OS X]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="os-x"><![CDATA[OS X]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[OSX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="osx"><![CDATA[OSX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Updates]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="updates"><![CDATA[Updates]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/08/the-mac-os-x-10-5-8-update-is-now-available/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Mac OS X 10.5.8 update is now available through Software Update. Among the listed features are resolution for compatibility issues when joining AirPort networks, disappearing monitor resolutions in System Preferences, and Bluetooth reliability. 
<p><a href="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/08/l_500_160_31234E4C-7C7D-452E-AEDF-80F0C347A69C.jpeg"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/08/l_500_160_31234E4C-7C7D-452E-AEDF-80F0C347A69C.jpeg" alt="" width="300" height="96" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-364" /></a></p>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>Need Caffeine ?</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/need-caffeine/</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 12 Aug 2009 18:57:15 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Internet]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="internet"><![CDATA[Internet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Bing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="bing"><![CDATA[Bing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Caffeine]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="caffeine"><![CDATA[Caffeine]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[google]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="google"><![CDATA[google]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Microsoft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="microsoft"><![CDATA[Microsoft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Search Engines]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="search-engines"><![CDATA[Search Engines]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=217</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[Google has lifted the lid on its updated search engine, which developers have nicknamed "Caffeine".

Although still in the testing phase, the firm says it is the "first step in improving the speed, accuracy and comprehensiveness of search results". 

Martin McNulty of search marketing specialist Trafficbroker said the upgrade threatened to put Microsoft's new engine, Bing, "in the shade".

"Google have let Caffeine quietly slip out. It talked about vertical specific searches while quietly doubling the speed and starts introducing real-time results and news feeds," he said.

"Bing was launched with a massive media budget.

"Trouble is, Bing presents itself as an alternative to something that users are still - for now - happy with," he added. 

]]></content:encoded>

<title>What&#039;s Inside ?</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/whats-inside/</link>
<pubDate>Thu, 13 Aug 2009 10:32:57 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/article/features/autopsy">Maximum PC</a> has a great article about the insides of some common hardware.

Quite useful and informative...

My favs are:

Western Digital VelociRapter 3000BLS Hard Drive
<a href = "http://www.alecksdad.com/images/crop_full.jpg" target = "_blank">
<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/08/592C8140-1FDD-4D73-AA19-8062C83C9F54.jpg" alt="592C8140-1FDD-4D73-AA19-8062C83C9F54.jpg" border="0" width="405" height="598" /></div>
</a>


Western Digital MyBook World Edition 1TB NAS
<a href = "http://www.alecksdad.com/images/wd_full.jpg" target = "_blank">
<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/08/616BDAD1-1D76-4B55-A0A0-68824D5984F0.jpg" alt="616BDAD1-1D76-4B55-A0A0-68824D5984F0.jpg" border="0" width="405" height="598" /></div>
</a>

Apple iPhone

<title>Why does Evernote Rock ?</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/why-does-evernote-rock/</link>
<pubDate>Fri, 14 Aug 2009 18:54:52 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

<content:encoded><![CDATA[Because it keeps getting better and better...

From the <a href="http://blog.evernote.com/2009/08/14/send-blog-posts-from-google-reader-to-evernote/">Evernote Blog:</a>


<strong>How to Send Blog Posts from Google Reader to Evernote
</strong>
August 14th, 2009

Google Reader now lets you send blog posts directly into Evernote. When you send a post to Evernote, we go out to the source page and clip the whole thing â€“that way you get everything, not just the bit that you see in Reader.
Why I love this feature

A lot of my web life can be broadly classified as research: recipes, drool-worthy gadgets, lifehacking ideas, articles to read, etc. Much of that stuff enter my consciousness through Google Reader. The usual workflow is something likeâ€“see an interesting post, go to the blog, clip it into Evernote for later, return to Reader. Now, I can do everything without leaving Reader. Awesome.

<strong>Super simple setup
</strong>
<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/08/7E7B48A6-F337-4543-9A5E-690A058B8D0B.jpg" alt="7E7B48A6-F337-4543-9A5E-690A058B8D0B.jpg" border="0" width="450"/></div>

Sign into Google Reader and click on the Settings link at the top of the page, then click on the â€œSend Toâ€ tab. Next, click â€œCreate a Custom Linkâ€ and enter the following:

    * Name: Evernote
    * URL: http://s.evernote.com/grclip?url=${url}&title=${title}
    * Icon URL: http://www.evernote.com/favicon.ico

And youâ€™re done!

<strong>What happens next</strong>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/08/9107925A-FB7B-4516-9302-B7DEBADC9DA7.jpg" alt="9107925A-FB7B-4516-9302-B7DEBADC9DA7.jpg" border="0" width="448" height="124" /></div>

When you click your shiny new Send to Evernote button, a new tab will open asking you to sign into Evernote (if you havenâ€™t done so recently), and to, optionally, select the destination notebook and add tags.
A little note

The results you will see are identical to clipping whole webpages using any of our web clippers, which means that youâ€™ll get the content you want and some of the webpage element, too. ]]></content:encoded>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/08/0EFC4A1A-D356-416A-9E89-9C0547B851D4.jpg" alt="0EFC4A1A-D356-416A-9E89-9C0547B851D4.jpg" border="0" width="450" height="343" /></div>

UK network operator 3 is to launch a multi-user mobile Wi-Fi dongle by Christmas.

The 86 x 45 x 10mm device will allow you to create a personal Wi-Fi connection while on the move â€“ provided youâ€™re within range of 3â€™s network, of course. You wonâ€™t have to install any software on your laptop, simply power-up the unit and jump onto the Wi-Fi connection it then picks up.]]></content:encoded>

<title>IBM to use DNA for Next Gen Computer</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/ibm-to-use-dna-for-next-gen-computer/</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 19 Aug 2009 07:33:56 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="hardware"><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[DNA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="dna"><![CDATA[DNA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[IBM]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="ibm"><![CDATA[IBM]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Next Generation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="next-generation"><![CDATA[Next Generation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Scientists]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="scientists"><![CDATA[Scientists]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Semiconductors]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="semiconductors"><![CDATA[Semiconductors]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Super Computers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="super-computers"><![CDATA[Super Computers]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=272</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[Scientists working for IBM may have found a way to use DNA - the basic building block of life - to help construct the next generation of semiconductor chips in a breakthrough that would replace the hugely expensive and complex machinery currently used.

Scientists have suggested that artificial DNA nanostructures and "DNA origami", in which a long single strand of DNA is folded into a shape using shorter "staple strands", could be used to provide a template for the self-assembly of other materials into nanoelectronic or nano-optical devices on the surface of the chip.

Normally, however, DNA origami is formed in solution and uncontrolled deposition results in random arrangements rather than the predictable and repetitive patterns needed to build microcircuitry.

In a research paper published yesterday in Nature Nanotechnology, the scientific journal, the scientists working at IBM's Almaden Research Center and the California Institute of Technology suggested using electron-beam lithography and an etching process to create DNA origami-shaped "binding sites" on silicon and other materials used in chipmaking.


]]></content:encoded>
<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<title>BT completes 20Mbits/sec broadband boost</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/bt-completes-20mbitssec-broadband-boost/</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 19 Aug 2009 07:45:29 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Internet]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=274</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[BT has announced that it's finished upgrading hundreds of its telephone exchanges in a move the company says will increase headline broadband speeds to 20Mbits/sec.

The speed tweak â€“ from "up to" 8Mbits/sec â€“ will be free for customers lucky enough to live in enabled areas, and is accompanied by an increase in theoretical upstream speeds from 448Kbits/sec to 1Mbits/sec.

The revved-up service will initially only be available for BT Retail customers connecting through 549 exchanges that serve approximately 40% of the UK's homes and businesses, although the company hopes to increase reach to 55% by March next year. We're waiting to here back from BT on which areas will receive the speed boost.

<a href="http://www.pcpro.co.uk/news/350845/bt-completes-20mbits-sec-broadband-boost">Source</a>]]></content:encoded>
