<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=412</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[Vodafone and Apple today confirmed that they have reached agreement to bring iPhone 3G and iPhone 3GS to the UK and Ireland in early 2010.

<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/A746E348-9AA0-4D67-ADD0-9986DD7CE29A.jpg" alt="A746E348-9AA0-4D67-ADD0-9986DD7CE29A.jpg" border="0" width="200" height="350" align="left" />

Beginning today, Vodafone UK and Vodafone Ireland customers can register their interest in iPhone 3G and iPhone 3GS at <a href="http://www.vodafone.co.uk/iphone">www.vodafone.co.uk/iphone</a> and <a href="http://www.vodafone.ie/iphone">www.vodafone.ie/iphone</a> respectively. Pricing, tariffs and availability information will be announced locally in the future.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>24D731CE-07C5-4C90-81C6-65DEE244B3B6.jpg</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/?attachment_id=414</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 30 Sep 2009 13:32:58 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

<title>EyeTV on your iPhone</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/eyetv-on-your-iphone/</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 30 Sep 2009 13:38:13 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="hardware"><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iphone"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="apple"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Apps]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="apps"><![CDATA[Apps]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[EyeTV]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="eyetv"><![CDATA[EyeTV]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="hardware"><![CDATA[Hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="iphone"><![CDATA[iPhone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mac]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mac"><![CDATA[Mac]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=417</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.elgato.com/elgato/int.html">Elgato Systems</a> has released an iPhone app that allows you to watch, live and recorded TV on your iPhone or iPod Touch.

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/24D731CE-07C5-4C90-81C6-65DEE244B3B6.jpg" alt="24D731CE-07C5-4C90-81C6-65DEE244B3B6.jpg" border="0" width="500" /></div>

The EyeTV application accesses EyeTV running on your Mac at home.

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/5BE5E528-AC42-42B4-83EE-670FC0381433.jpg" alt="5BE5E528-AC42-42B4-83EE-670FC0381433.jpg" border="0" width="479" height="299" /></div>

The EyeTV running on your Mac converts live TV to the correct format for streaming to the iPhone, ensuring optimal picture quality.

<img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/A602FE86-07A5-4B0A-85D2-57455F1509D9.jpg" alt="A602FE86-07A5-4B0A-85D2-57455F1509D9.jpg" border="0" width="318" height="459" align="right" />

I've been holding off getting an EyeTV device, but this new feature sounds very good.

Does anyone out there have an EyeTV stick or even better the iPhone app as well ? ?

Let us know how well it works...?

]]></content:encoded>

<content:encoded><![CDATA[Microsoft Security Essentials free antivirus app leaves beta.

<blockquote>"Microsoft Security Essentials provides real-time protection for your home PC that guards against viruses, spyware, and other malicious software."</blockquote>


<a href = "http://www.microsoft.com/security_essentials/" target = "_blank"><div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/screenshot.jpg" alt="screenshot.jpg" border="0" width="500" height="226" /></div></a>



Would you switch from your current virus protection to this app ?

If you've used this software, let us know what you think of it...]]></content:encoded>

PSP firmware update version 6.10 will bring new features to existing PSPs and to the new PSP Go â€“ set to be released in the UK tomorrow. But its Sonyâ€™s mention of tethering that has really got gamers excited.

<title>Book Review: The Best Camera is the One That&#039;s with You: iPhone Photography by Chase Jarvis</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/book-review-the-best-camera-is-the-one-thats-with-you-iphone-photography-by-chase-jarvis/</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 07 Oct 2009 07:56:58 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/10/book-review-the-best-camera-is-the-one-thats-with-you-iphone-photography-by-chase-jarvis/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div><br /><h4>Sent to you via Google Reader</h4><h2><a href="http://www.iphoneography.com/journal/2009/10/6/book-review-the-best-camera-is-the-one-thats-with-you-iphone.html">Book Review: The Best Camera is the One That's with You: iPhone Photography by Chase Jarvis</a></h2><p style="text-align: justify;"><span><span><img src="http://www.iphoneography.com/storage/Chase_Javis_book_061009.gif?__SQUARESPACE_CACHEVERSION=1254811024427" alt="" /></span></span>Chase Jarvis's iPhone photography ecosystem rolls on with the 3rd element in this project. First came the app <a href="http://www.iphoneography.com/journal/2009/9/28/is-best-camera-really-the-best-app.html" target="_blank">'Best Camera'</a> and community website <a href="http://www.thebestcamera.com/" target="_blank">'The Best Camera'</a>, and now his book of photos all taken with his iPhone, titled <a href="http://www.thebestcamera.com/book.html" target="_blank">'The Best Camera is the One That's with You'</a> has hit the streets.<p />The book is a nicely presented 6"x6" paper back containing over 200 photos charting the past year of Chase's iPhoneography journey, and contains a wide range of iPhone photos, which depending on your tastes you will either like, dislike or think are just plain rubbish, but in Chase's words <em>"What you're holding in your hands is a chunk of me. My guts. My process. My study. It's a look into the production of my ideas."</em><p />As you flick through the book you will notice that each photo has a description of some kind, and then at irregular intervals Chase breaks up his photos by adding a little note about that photo on the facing page.<p />Like Chase says <em>"Writers have notepads, painters have sketchbooks, and I have a camera that's always with me"</em>, and this statement is true for all photographers, whether they be regular photographers or iPhoneographers.</p><br /><p style="text-align: justify;">Overall this is a nice book of photo art that should appeal to most of us, inspiring us all to shoot more photos with our iPhones, and priced at a reasonable Â£11.99/$13.59 from Amazon (although prices will vary) will sit nicely on any iPhoneographers coffee table.</p></div><div></div><div><p />Sent from my iPhone</div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/book-review-the-best-camera-is-the-one-thats">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

<title>WD unveils new My Books with e-ink, while My Passport shrinks even further</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/wd-unveils-new-my-books-with-e-ink-while-my-passport-shrinks-even-further/</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 07 Oct 2009 08:07:14 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/10/wd-unveils-new-my-books-with-e-ink-while-my-passport-shrinks-even-further/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div><br /><h4>Sent to you via Google Reader</h4><h2><a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/10/06/wd-unveils-new-my-books-with-e-ink-while-my-passport-shrinks-ev/">WD unveils new My Books with e-ink, while My Passport shrinks even further</a></h2><div align="center"><img src="http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2009/10/091006-wd-01.jpg" border="1" alt="" /><p /><div align="left">Good news for hardcore portable storage buffs: looks like Western Digital is <a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/08/17/verbatim-insight-usb-drives-display-name-free-space-even-when-d/" target="_blank">taking a hint from Verbatim</a> and putting an e-ink display on its My Book Elite and My Book Studio portable hard drives, offering the device's label and free space up-front, perfect for those of us juggling multiple portable storage devices. In addition, both offer WD SmartWare, 256-bit hardware-based encryption, and are available in capacities ranging from 500GB to 2TB. My Book Studio (formatted for Mac and sportin' a FireWire 800 interface) ranges from $149.99 to $299.99 depending on size, while My Book Elite (with a USB 2.0 interface and NTFS formatting) will run you anywhere from $169.99 to $279.99.<p />If what you're looking for however, is the company's "smallest drive to date," check out My Passport Elite. Featuring a USB dock, illuminated capacity gauge, a secure "drive lock" indicator, and that 256-bit hardware-based encryption, this bad boy is sports up to 640GB storage (which will run you $169.99). This one is available in one of three "metallic" colors -- Metallic Red, Metallic Blue, or Charcoal Metallic. Sadly, the company hasn't yet teamed up with <a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/08/31/musicskins-slathers-seagate-hdds-with-famous-musicians-hasselho/" target="_blank">MusicSkins</a> for a Metallica skin -- but our fingers are crossed.<p /><a href="http://store.westerndigital.com/store/wdus/en_US/DisplayProductDetailsPage/categoryID.15206100/parid.13092300/catid.15146100" target="_blank">Read</a> - My Book Studio<br /><a href="http://store.westerndigital.com/store/wdus/en_US/DisplayProductDetailsPage/categoryID.33179300/parid.13092300/catid.13092800" target="_blank">Read</a> - My Book Elite<br /><a href="http://store.westerndigital.com/store/wdus/en_US/DisplayProductDetailsPage/categoryID.13094200/parid.13092300/catid.13093000" target="_blank">Read</a> - My Passport Elite</div><br /></div><p>Filed under: <a href="http://www.engadget.com/category/storage/" rel="tag" target="_blank">Storage</a></p><p style="padding: 5px; background: #ddd; border: 1px solid #ccc; clear: both;"><a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/10/06/wd-unveils-new-my-books-with-e-ink-while-my-passport-shrinks-ev/" target="_blank">WD unveils new My Books with e-ink, while My Passport shrinks even further</a> originally appeared on <a href="http://www.engadget.com" target="_blank">Engadget</a> on Tue, 06 Oct 2009 10:23:00 EST. Please see our <a href="http://www.weblogsinc.com/feed-terms/" target="_blank">terms for use of feeds</a>.</p><h6 style="clear: both; padding: 8px 0 0 0; height: 2px; font-size: 1px; border: 0; margin: 0; padding: 0;"></h6></div><div></div><div><p />Sent from my iPhone</div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/wd-unveils-new-my-books-with-e-ink-while-my-p">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

<title>Ways to Be Kind to Your Battery</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/ways-to-be-kind-to-your-battery/</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 07 Oct 2009 09:59:21 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/10/ways-to-be-kind-to-your-battery/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="http://posterous.com/getfile/files.posterous.com/danielhpavey/YRAWGA01gT9J2gEQws2tsDGFcNbGNPSsAGa965UvhSfZ8c5BPLUnGTc2bYIe/greenest_macbooks1.jpg" width="500" height="315"/> <p><a href="http://theappleblog.com/2009/10/06/14-ways-to-be-kind-to-your-battery/">The Apple Blog</a> has a nice article on how to improve the battery life of your MacBook.<p /> Here are their top tips:<p /><b>1. Dim the screen<br /></b><br />Relatively speaking, that LED panel uses a fabulous amount of power, and, most of the time, simply doesnâ€™t need to be so super bright. Turn it down to a comfortable level where you donâ€™t have to squint to see what youâ€™re doing.</p><div> <br /><b>2. Dim the Keyboard</b><p />The optical fiber backlighting in the keyboard can sometimes be brought to life even when you can see the keys perfectly well. When that happens, you can probably afford to turn it down a bit.<p /> </div><div><b>3. Stop Playing DVDs/CDsâ€¦</b><p />Your optical drive uses a motor. And a laser. They exhaust batteries in no time.<p /></div><div><b>4. â€¦and Stop Playing Video/Music from the HDD</b><p />Sorry, I know you stopped using your Optical Drive, but playing music or video is a power-guzzling process irrespective of where the source files happen to be.<p /> </div><div><b>5. Spin Down That Disc</b><p />Avoid doing anything that requires the hard drive to spin. Be mindful of the applications you run, and avoid those which require lots of read/write activity. Also, pop in to your System Preferences â†’ Energy Saver and select â€œPut the hard disk(s) to sleep whenever possible.â€<p /> </div><div><b>6. Go Easy on Your CPU</b><p />You canâ€™t put the CPU to sleep, but you can go easy on it. Cycles spent crunching numbers equals battery drain. Quit anything you absolutely do not need. Mail, iCal, iTunes and goodness knows what else, even when hidden, are claiming CPU cycles.<p /> </div><div><b>7. Select the Right Video Card</b><p />If you own a late 2008 model MacBook Pro or later, youâ€™ll have two graphic chips at your disposal. Thereâ€™s the NVIDIA 9600, ideal for web browsing and text editing, or the more powerful 9600M, a better choice for gaming and video editing. In your System Preferences, choose Energy Saver and select Graphics: Better Battery Life. This will tell Mac OS X to use the 9600 chipset rather than its power-crazed big brother.<p /> </div><div><b>8. Internal Fans</b><p />Your MacBook should do a decent job of managing its own internal cooling, but if youâ€™re competent doing this yourself, you might consider using a tool like smcFanControl to spin those things down. Just donâ€™t blame me if you melt your MacBook as a result. (Seriously, if you donâ€™t know what youâ€™re doing, donâ€™t even try this tip!)<p /> </div><div><b>9. Switch Off the Radios</b><p />Your Wi-Fi and bluetooth radios donâ€™t have to be on all the time, do they? If preserving power matters to you, turn them off.<p /></div><div><b>10. Ditch the Mouse</b><p /> If your bluetooth radio is turned off, you can pack away that wireless Mighty Mouse. Using a wired Mighty Mouse? You should pack that away, too; that laser is sucking-up the juice.<p /></div><div><b>11. Unplug That iPod!</b><p /> If you keep your iPod or iPhone connected to your MacBook, remove them. Even if youâ€™re not actively syncing them (and youâ€™re not â€” if you followed my advice, iTunes is turned off by now) theyâ€™re keeping their own batteries topped-up via that good old USB copper. Your MacBookâ€™s battery will thank you for unplugging them.<br /> <b><br /></b></div><div><b>12. External Drives</b><p />If youâ€™re using USB-powered external hard drives for backup/storage, unplug them (but be aware this means your backup routine may be disrupted!) Even if youâ€™re not using your external drive all the time, remember that if you invoke an Open or Save As dialogue, those connected storage devices will spin-up on the off-chance you want to use them. If you donâ€™t, that was power wasted!<p /> </div><div><b>13. Close the Lid</b><p />If you are going to be inactive for a while, consider putting the machine to sleep (or if youâ€™ll be inactive for a long time, go one better and shut-down completely.)<br /><b><br /> </b></div><div><b>14. Plan Ahead</b><p />If itâ€™s at all practicable, plan what you are going to do before you even power-up your MacBook.</div><p /><p /><div>Nice list, thanks guys!</div><p /> <div>Does anyone have any other tips ?</div><p /><div>Let us know...</div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/ways-to-be-kind-to-your-battery">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

<title>Mac OS X&#039;s Hidden Single-Application Mode</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/mac-os-xs-hidden-single-application-mode/</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 07 Oct 2009 11:11:51 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="software"><![CDATA[Software]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Tips]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="tips"><![CDATA[Tips]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="apple"><![CDATA[Apple]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mac]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mac"><![CDATA[Mac]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[OS]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="os"><![CDATA[OS]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[OS X]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="os-x"><![CDATA[OS X]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[OSX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="osx"><![CDATA[OSX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Tips]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="tips"><![CDATA[Tips]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=438</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[This is a really interesting tip.

I'm running with it now to see how I get on.

<a href="http://db.tidbits.com/article/10624">Apparently</a> 

<blockquote>"Back in 1999, when Steve Jobs first showed off the new Finder in Mac OS X, it ran in a single-application mode, where switching from one application to another caused the first application to minimize (this was the original demo of the Genie effect1). This was intended to be the default behavior, but it was so widely reviled that Apple quickly changed the default to the familiar multi-application mode that shows multiple applications on the screen at the same time."</blockquote>


Lurking in the scary bowels of Mac OS X for all these years has been this little command, which brings back single-application mode. (Go ahead and try it - it's easily reversed.)

defaults write com.apple.dock single-app -bool true

For single-application mode to take effect, you have to relaunch the Dock with this second command.

killall Dock 

To go back again:

defaults delete com.apple.dock single-app
killall Dock


<blockquote>"The most important fact to realize is that single-application mode is tied exclusively to the Dock. This means that if you click an application's icon in the Dock, it immediately hides all the other applications, including the Finder.

However, if you switch applications through any other method, including clicking another visible application's window and the Command-Tab application switcher, Mac OS X's normal multi-application approach remains in effect, and nothing will be hidden.

You can thus combine methods of switching between applications."</blockquote>

Groovy...

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/10/33F558B7-A29B-4F5C-AC49-8914EE5CF803.jpg" alt="33F558B7-A29B-4F5C-AC49-8914EE5CF803.jpg" border="0" width="480" height="301" /></div>]]></content:encoded>
<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

<title>Unbelievable: &quot;123456&quot; Most Common Hotmail Password</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/unbelievable-123456-most-common-hotmail-password/</link>
<pubDate>Wed, 07 Oct 2009 19:05:35 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/10/unbelievable-123456-most-common-hotmail-password/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[  <div style="font-family: sans-serif; overflow: auto; margin: 0px 10px;"><h2 style="margin: 0.25em 0 0 0;" /><div class=""><a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/article/news/unbelievable_123456_most_common_hotmail_password">Unbelievable: &quot;123456&quot; Most Common Hotmail Password</a></div></h2> <div style="margin-bottom: 0.5em;">via <a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/articles/all" class="f">Maximum PC all RSS Feed</a> by Paul Lilly on 10/7/09</div><br style="display: none;" /> <p>Over 10,000 Hotmail email accounts were <a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/article/news/10000_hotmail_accounts_compromised_phishing_campaign">leaked to the web</a> earlier this week as the result of a massive phishing scam, which may not have taken a whole lot of effort. After all, if you&#39;re going to choose &quot;123456&quot; as your password, compromising your account is like shooting fish in a barrel.</p> <p>In this case, there were 64 said fish in a barrel full of over 10,000 compromised Hotmail accounts, making it the <a href="http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2009/10/10000-passwords/">most commonly used password</a> of the bunch, according to a researcher who combed through all the posted accounts.</p> <p>About 42 percent of the passwords consisted of lowercase letters from &quot;a&quot; to &quot;z,&quot; and just 6 percent secured their email accounts by mixing alpha-numeric characters. And almost 2,000 passwords were only six characters long (the longest was 30 characters).</p> <p>An interesting side note - a bunch of the top 20 passwords were Spanish names, which might suggest that the victims were of Spanish origin or lived in Spanish-speaking communities, Wired.com reports. </p> <p align="center"><img src="http://www.maximumpc.com/files/u69/Facepalms.png" height="350" width="405" /> </p></div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/unbelievable-123456-most-common-hotmail-passw">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

<title>BT to double homes on ultra-fast broadband</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/bt-to-double-homes-on-ultra-fast-broadband/</link>
<pubDate>Sun, 11 Oct 2009 08:20:49 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

<title>Jailbroken iPhone gets Expose-like view, you retail users just keep on scrollin&#039; (video)</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/jailbroken-iphone-gets-expose-like-view-you-retail-users-just-keep-on-scrollin-video/</link>
<pubDate>Fri, 16 Oct 2009 08:08:49 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/10/jailbroken-iphone-gets-expose-like-view-you-retail-users-just-keep-on-scrollin-video/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div><br /><h4>Sent to you via Google Reader</h4><h2><a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/10/15/jailbroken-iphone-gets-expose-like-view-you-retail-users-just-k/">Jailbroken iPhone gets Expose-like view, you retail users just keep on scrollin' (video)</a></h2><div align="center"><a href="http://www.slashgear.com/iphone-3gs-gets-expose-hack-video-1560539/" target="_blank"><img src="http://www.blogcdn.com/www.engadget.com/media/2009/10/expose-iphone-20091015-412.jpg" border="1" alt="Jailbroken iPhone gets Expose-like view, you retail users just keep on scrollin' (video)" /></a><br /></div><br />How many apps do you have on your iPhone? Yeah, we figured it was a lot. Being able to <a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/09/09/itunes-9-bringing-itunes-lp-functionality-mentioned-in-new-del/" target="_blank">re-arrange items</a> now is mighty helpful, but not so helpful as this little hack from Steve Troughton-Smith that adds ExposÃ©-like functionality to the mix. Just press the Home button and up pops a view of all the application pages; tap one and you're taken straight there, as shown in the video after the break. Nice and simple -- and at this point not available even to jailbroken handsets. We're sure that'll change soon, but it's anybody's guess if or when Apple will add something like this to the official OS. Yet another reason to go ahead and roll your own.<p><a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/10/15/jailbroken-iphone-gets-expose-like-view-you-retail-users-just-k/" rel="bookmark" target="_blank">Continue reading <em>Jailbroken iPhone gets Expose-like view, you retail users just keep on scrollin' (video)</em></a></p><p>Filed under: <a href="http://www.engadget.com/category/cellphones/" rel="tag" target="_blank">Cellphones</a></p><p style="padding: 5px; background: #ddd; border: 1px solid #ccc; clear: both;"><a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/10/15/jailbroken-iphone-gets-expose-like-view-you-retail-users-just-k/" target="_blank">Jailbroken iPhone gets Expose-like view, you retail users just keep on scrollin' (video)</a> originally appeared on <a href="http://www.engadget.com" target="_blank">Engadget</a> on Thu, 15 Oct 2009 08:33:00 EST. Please see our <a href="http://www.weblogsinc.com/feed-terms/" target="_blank">terms for use of feeds</a>.</p><h6 style="clear: both; padding: 8px 0 0 0; height: 2px; font-size: 1px; border: 0; margin: 0; padding: 0;"></h6><a href="http://www.slashgear.com/iphone-3gs-gets-expose-hack-video-1560539/" target="_blank">Read</a>&nbsp;|&nbsp;<a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/10/15/jailbroken-iphone-gets-expose-like-view-you-retail-users-just-k/" title="Permanent link to this entry" rel="bookmark" target="_blank">Permalink</a>&nbsp;|&nbsp;<a href="http://www.engadget.com/forward/19196851/" title="Send this entry to a friend via email" target="_blank">Email this</a>&nbsp;|&nbsp;<a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/10/15/jailbroken-iphone-gets-expose-like-view-you-retail-users-just-k/#comments" title="View reader comments on this entry" target="_blank">Comments</a></div><div></div><div><p />Sent from my iPhone</div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/jailbroken-iphone-gets-expose-like-view-you-r">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

<title>Facebook accounts for a seventh of UK web traffic </title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/facebook-accounts-for-a-seventh-of-uk-web-traffic/</link>
<pubDate>Fri, 16 Oct 2009 15:37:39 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[Internet]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="internet"><![CDATA[Internet]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/10/facebook-accounts-for-a-seventh-of-uk-web-traffic/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://posterous.com/getfile/files.posterous.com/danielhpavey/rmyKuxm8PqMInkh1zUzLeLJhZFFfpwEoYntJOXruEeI0RzPftYrsIv40YNLe/it_photo_138229_52.jpg"><img src="http://posterous.com/getfile/files.posterous.com/danielhpavey/8V0boF4FrGYfwjQKcSUv5usP3S8EzHHILlOQMX2YgBgYVpX6TJ09RqbcPkuT/it_photo_138229_52.jpg.scaled.500.jpg" width="500" height="374"/></a> <p></p><div class="gmail_quote"><a href="http://www.pcpro.co.uk/news/352546/facebook-accounts-for-a-seventh-of-uk-web-traffic" target="_blank">PC Pro is reporting that</a>:<p /><div>&quot;The social-networking site Facebook accounts for an astonishing one in seven internet page views in the UK.&quot;</div><p /><div>While <a href="http://Google.co.uk" target="_blank">Google.co.uk</a> remains the most visited site in this country, Facebook wins hands down in terms of the number of clicks it generates, accounting for 14.5% of all web traffic.</div><p /><div>&quot;Although it has fallen somewhat off the media radar in favour of Twitter recently, Facebook remains far and away the most popular social networking website in the UK,&quot; claims Hitwise&#39;s research director, Robin Goad.</div><p /><p /> </div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/facebook-accounts-for-a-seventh-of-uk-web-tra">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

<item>
<title>YouTube to screen Channel 4 shows</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/youtube-to-screen-channel-4-shows/</link>
<pubDate>Fri, 16 Oct 2009 15:53:57 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[Daniel]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Channel 4]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="channel-4"><![CDATA[Channel 4]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Internet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="internet"><![CDATA[Internet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[social]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="social"><![CDATA[social]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[web]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="web"><![CDATA[web]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[YouTube]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="youtube"><![CDATA[YouTube]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/?p=453</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[PC Pro are <a href="http://www.pcpro.co.uk/news/352549/youtube-to-screen-channel-4-shows">reporting</a> that:

<blockquote>"YouTube has signed a ground-breaking deal with Channel 4 to make full-length episodes of series such as Skins available shortly after broadcast."</blockquote>

<div style="text-align:center;"><img src="http://www.alecksdad.com/http://www.alecksdad.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/10/Screen-shot-2009-10-16-at-16.52.30.png" alt="Screen shot 2009-10-16 at 16.52.30.png" border="0" width="" height="" /></div>

The companies claim the deal has been under negotiation for the past six months and will see YouTube granted access to the entire 4oD back catalogue, consisting of around 3,000 hours' worth of shows including Brass Eye and Ramsay's Kitchen Nightmares.

New shows will appear on YouTube shortly after they're aired.

"Making our programmes directly accessible to YouTube's 20 million UK users will financially benefit both Channel 4 and our independent production partners and help bolster our investment in quality British content," claims Andy Duncan, the Channel 4 chief executive.


Pretty soon I'm just gonna bin my TV ! ! ]]></content:encoded>

That's rubbish ! !

<item>
<title>Corsair Releases &quot;Practically Indestructible&quot; 64GB Flash Drive</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/corsair-releases-practically-indestructible-64gb-flash-drive/</link>
<pubDate>Sat, 17 Oct 2009 17:09:21 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/10/corsair-releases-practically-indestructible-64gb-flash-drive/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[  <div style="font-family: sans-serif; overflow: auto; margin: 0px 10px;"><h2 style="margin: 0.25em 0 0 0;" /><div class=""><a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/article/news/corsair_releases_practically_indestructible_64gb_flash_drive">Corsair Releases &quot;Practically Indestructible&quot; 64GB Flash Drive</a></div></h2> <div style="margin-bottom: 0.5em;">via <a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/articles/all" class="f">Maximum PC all RSS Feed</a> by Paul Lilly on 10/16/09</div><br style="display: none;" /> <p>Corsair on Thursday <a href="http://www.corsair.com/news/press_release.aspx?id=1160197">announced </a>its new 64GB Flash Survivor USB drive, which the company claims is the &quot;most rugged high-capacity flash drive on the market.&quot; And by the looks of things, they&#39;re probably right.</p> <p>Encased in CNC-milled, aircraft grade aluminum, Corsair says the new drive is pretty much indestructible. Each unit comes molded in a shock-dampening collar and EPDM seal, providing water-resistance up to a depth of 200 meters. Corsair notes that reviewers have dropped, baked, boiled, microwaved, and even run over the Survivor with an SUV in an attempt to show just how durable the drive really is.</p> <p>&quot;The new 64GB Flash Survivor takes the industry&#39;s most popular rugged USB drive and takes it to the next level, with a huge amount of storage space, plus best-in-class performance,&quot; said Jim Carlton, VP of Marketing for Corsair. &quot;The 64GB Survivor is ideal for storing and transporting your music, videos, pictures, and other important files, safe in the knowledge that your data will be safeguarded inside the Survivor&#39;s protective shell.&quot;</p> <p>The drive is <a href="http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002R5AM2M">available now</a> with a street price around $170. To help justify the cost, Corsair says each drive comes bundled with a USB extension cable and dog tags, and comes backed by a 10-year warranty.</p> <p align="center"><img src="http://www.maximumpc.com/files/u69/Corsair_Survivor.png" height="226" width="375" /></p> <p><span style="font-size: xx-small;">Image Credit: Corsair via Legit Reviews </span></p></div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/corsair-releases-practically-indestructible-6">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

<title>Apple Introduces Magic Mouse</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/apple-introduces-magic-mouse/</link>
<pubDate>Tue, 20 Oct 2009 19:51:03 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/10/apple-introduces-magic-mouse/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[  <div style="font-family: sans-serif; overflow: auto; margin: 0px 10px;"><h2 style="margin: 0.25em 0 0 0;" /><div class=""><a href="http://www.apple.com/magicmouse/?sr=hotnews.rss">Apple Introduces Magic Mouse</a></div></h2> <div style="margin-bottom: 0.5em;">via <a href="http://www.apple.com/hotnews/" class="f">Apple Hot News</a> on 10/20/09</div><br style="display: none;" /> Today Apple introduced the new wireless Magic Mouse, the first mouse to use Appleâ€™s revolutionary Multi-Touch technology. Pioneered on iPhone, iPod touch and Mac notebook trackpads, Multi-Touch allows customers to navigate using intuitive finger gestures. Instead of mechanical buttons, scroll wheels or scroll balls, the entire top of the Magic Mouse is a seamless Multi-Touch surface. Magic Mouse comes standard with the new iMac and will be available as a Mac accessory at just $69.</div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/apple-introduces-magic-mouse-1">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

The new iMac line, starting at $1,199, is the fastest ever with Intel Core 2 Duo processors starting at 3.06 GHz, and Core i5 and i7 quad-core processors for up to twice the performance. Every new iMac ships with a wireless keyboard and the all new wireless Magic Mouse, the worldâ€™s first mouse with Multi-Touch technology.</div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/apple-unveils-new-imac-with-215-and-27-inch-d">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

<content:encoded><![CDATA[  <div style="font-family: sans-serif; overflow: auto; margin: 0px 10px;"><h2 style="margin: 0.25em 0 0 0;" /><div class=""><a href="http://www.apple.com/macbook/?sr=hotnews.rss">Apple Updates MacBook</a></div></h2> <div style="margin-bottom: 0.5em;">via <a href="http://www.apple.com/hotnews/" class="f">Apple Hot News</a> on 10/20/09</div><br style="display: none;" /> Apple today updated its popular MacBook with a new, durable polycarbonate unibody design featuring a brilliant LED-backlit display, a glass Multi-Touch trackpad and Appleâ€™s innovative built-in battery for up to seven hours of battery life. Inheriting technology and design features from the MacBook Pro line, the new MacBook is an ideal consumer notebook for students and new Mac users, and is available for $999.</div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/apple-updates-macbook">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

<title>Lifehacker&#039;s Complete Guide to Windows 7 [Windows 7]</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/lifehackers-complete-guide-to-windows-7-windows-7/</link>
<pubDate>Fri, 23 Oct 2009 17:37:09 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/10/lifehackers-complete-guide-to-windows-7-windows-7/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[  <div style="font-family: sans-serif; overflow: auto; margin: 0px 10px;"><h2 style="margin: 0.25em 0 0 0;" /><div class=""><a href="http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/lifehacker/full/~3/nhQwwDGgttY/lifehackers-complete-guide-to-windows-7">Lifehacker&#39;s Complete Guide to Windows 7 [Windows 7]</a></div></h2> <div style="margin-bottom: 0.5em;">via <a href="http://lifehacker.com" class="f">Lifehacker</a> by Kevin Purdy on 10/22/09</div><br style="display: none;" /> <p><a href="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/lifehacker/2009/10/win-7-guide-head.png" rel="lytebox"><img src="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/17/2009/10/500x_win-7-guide-head.jpg" width="500" /></a>Windows 7 officially launches today, but we've been testing, tweaking, customizing, fixing, and writing about this OS for a year now. We present here a guide to everything we've learned about the OS, from first install to final settings change.</p> <p>Whether you've played around with Windows 7 during its beta or release candidate versions, launch day is finally here, and Windows 7 is finally ready for widespread, public consumption. This guide will take you straight through from system requirements and upgrading your PC to highlighting Windows 7's best new features to helping you hit the ground running with all of the awesome tweaks Windows 7 has in store for you.</p> <h3 style="font-size: 120%; margin-top: 20px;">System Requirements</h3> <p><a href="http://windows.microsoft.com/systemrequirements">According to Microsoft</a>:</p> <blockquote> <ul> <li>1 gigahertz (GHz) or faster 32-bit (x86) or 64-bit (x64) processor</li> <li>1 gigabyte (GB) RAM (32-bit) or 2 GB RAM (64-bit)</li> <li>16 GB available hard disk space (32-bit) or 20 GB (64-bit)</li> <li>DirectX 9 graphics device with WDDM 1.0 or higher driver</li> </ul> </blockquote> <h3 style="font-size: 120%; margin-top: 20px;">Buying, installing, and upgrading</h3> <ul> <li><img src="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/lifehacker/2009/10/windows_7_chart.jpg" width="340" /><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5386523/figure-out-which-windows-7-edition-has-the-features-you-need">Figure Out Which Windows 7 Edition Has the Features You Need</a>: <em>Not everybody needs Windows 7 Ultimate, but what if there's a certain feature you must have when you grab your upgrade this Thursday? CNET breaks down each Windows 7 edition feature by feature in a handy chart.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5385127/prep-your-pc-for-windows-7">Prep Your PC for Windows 7</a>: <em>When Windows 7 drops this Thursday, you can either spend many, many hours watching a progress bar, or you can boot into a clean, speedy system with that new-OS smell. Let's get your system set up for a proper Windows 7 upgrade.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5361566/get-windows-7-home-premium-for-30-with-a-college-email-address">Get Windows 7 Home Premium for $30 With a College Email Address</a>: <em>If you're a U.S. college student, or at least having a working .edu email address, you don't have to pay $120 to upgrade Vista to Windows 7. You can get the Home Premium upgrade for just $30.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5341666/run-windows-7-for-120-days-without-activation">Run Windows 7 for 120 Days Without Activation</a>: <em>The command line code (<code>slmgr -rearm</code>) that could be entered at the end of three different 30-day periods to give Vista 120 days without activation works just the same in Windows 7.</em></li> </ul> <h3 style="font-size: 120%; margin-top: 20px;">Our take on Windows 7</h3> <ul> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5078582/top-10-things-to-look-forward-to-in-windows-7">Top 10 Things to Look Forward to in Windows 7</a>: <em>Windows 7 isn't a dramatic overhaul of its predecessor Windows Vista, but it does fix several sore spots and add a few welcome features.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5254211/windows-7s-best-underhyped-features">Windows 7's Best Underhyped Features</a>: <em>It's these less sexy, but very useful features, that make me think the more I use Windows 7, the less chance I'll ever use Vista or XP again.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5277207/windows-7-versus-mac-os-x-leopard-the-feature+by+feature-showdown">Windows 7 Versus Mac OS X Leopard: The Feature-by-Feature Showdown</a>: <em>Oh, I know: the Mac versus PC debate is so played out. Perhaps, but dumb commercials aside, if you're deciding between buying a Mac or a PC in the coming months, it helps to know what you're getting from one or the other.</em></li> </ul> <h3 style="font-size: 120%; margin-top: 20px;">New features</h3> <ul> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5132227/windows-7-tells-you-why-you-cant-touch-that-file">Windows 7 Tells You Why You Can't Touch That File</a>: <em>Windows 7 doesn't just give you a wagging finger (and pretend-useful "Try Again" button) when you want to move or delete a file that's in use. It actually tells you which application is using the file.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5170758/windows-7-lets-you-customize-your-logon-background">Windows 7 Lets You Customize Your Logon Background</a>: <em>Expert Windows hacker Rafael Rivera finds a change in the latest build of Windows 7â€”you can finally customize the log-on screen natively.</em></li> <li><img src="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/lifehacker/2009/10/windows_7_settings.jpg" width="340" /><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5360116/windows-7-transfers-your-wireless-settings-easily">Windows 7 Transfers Your Wireless Settings Easily</a>: <em>To transfer the settings for yourself, head into the Network and Sharing Center, click on Manage Wireless Networks, and then in the properties for your wireless network you'll find the link to open the wizard that will copy all your settings onto a flash drive.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5139424/how-to-burn-isos-in-windows-7">How to Burn ISOs in Windows 7</a>: <em>Burning that ISO to a disc is as simple as: 1. Double-click the ISO file (or right-click and select Burn disc image); 2. Click Burn.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5326409/play-your-ipod-through-your-windows-7-pcs-speakers">Play Your iPod Through Your Windows 7 PC's Speakers</a>: <em>You can play an external audio device through your computer's speakers without any extra software using a simple configuration setting.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5329964/windows-7-makes-uac-less-annoying-than-vista">Windows 7 Makes UAC Less Annoying Than Vista</a>: <em>The biggest change in Windows 7 is the new User Account Control &quot;slider&quot; setting, where you can choose your own balance between annoyance and securityâ€”but behind the scenes, Microsoft reduced the amount of actions that will prompt you.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5386078/netflix-update-comes-to-windows-7-media-center-looks-excellent">Netflix Update Comes to Windows 7 Media Center, Looks Excellent</a>: <em>Starting this week, Microsoft is rolling out an upgraded Watch Instantly interface to Windows 7 Media Center for users looking to get their streaming TV and movie fix on their upgraded PCs.</em></li> <li><img src="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/lifehacker/2009/10/printer_setup.jpg" width="340" /><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5262706/setup-file-and-printer-sharing-from-xp-to-windows-7">Setup File and Printer Sharing From XP to Windows 7</a>: <em>This guide walks you through the process of enabling network discovery, sharing your folders and printers, and accessing your shared resources from either Windows 7 or XP.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5242230/ie8-can-proactively-close-crashing-tabs-in-windows-7-rc">IE8 Can Proactively Close Crashing Tabs in Windows 7</a>: <em>The copy of IE8 found only in (Windows 7) has a "timer" that monitors new tabs as they open. If they aren't responsive within a relatively short amount of time, the browser will pop up and tell you this, possibly with a reason why, and ask whether you want to wait or kill the tab before it causes further problems.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5164286/windows-7-lets-you-finally-uninstall-internet-explorer-kinda">Windows 7 Lets You Finally Uninstall Internet Explorer (Kinda)</a>: <em>... It won&#39;t completely uninstallâ€”only the executable is actually removed. Still, being able to finally banish IE proper from your system is a pretty good start for folks who really don&#39;t like IE.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5165830/windows-7-will-let-you-uninstall-most-built+in-apps">Windows 7 Will Let You Uninstall Most Built-In Apps</a>: <em>You can turn almost every built-in application on or off, including Windows Search, Gadgets, and even Media Player.</em></li> </ul> <h3 style="font-size: 120%; margin-top: 20px;">The Taskbar</h3> <ul> <li> <embed type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowfullscreen="true" src="http://www.flickr.com/apps/video/stewart.swf?v=71377" allowscriptaccess="never" flashvars="intl_lang=en-us&amp;photo_secret=d90a4243f6&amp;photo_id=3005903840" height="269" wmode="transparent" width="340"></embed><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5077280/a-closer-look-at-windows-7s-aero-peek-feature">Aero Peek</a>: <em>Peek supercharges Windows' taskbar thumbnail previews, and lets you view, close, and switch between multiple windows by just hovering over the taskbar thumbnail, as well as pin programs to the taskbar permanently.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5372830/pin-individual-folders-to-the-windows-7-taskbar">Pin Individual Folders to the Windows 7 Taskbar</a>: <em>Windows 7's taskbar lets you pin any running program to the taskbar for easy future access, but it treats folders like second-class sub-items of the Explorer icon. Create a fake "program" to pin individual folder shortcuts to your taskbar.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5262386/middle+click-to-close-applications-from-windows-7s-taskbar">Middle-Click to Close Applications from Windows 7's Taskbar</a>: <em>In Windows 7, middle-clicking a taskbar button opens a new program instance. The easy solution for closing an app? Middle-click its preview window.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5336857/hold-shift-while-dragging-to-windows-7-taskbar-to-open-files">Hold Shift While Dragging to Windows 7 Taskbar to Open Files</a>: All you have to do is hold down the Shift key while dragging a file to an icon on the taskbar, and the tooltip will change to say "Open with" instead of pinning to the taskbar.</li> <li><img src="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/lifehacker/2009/10/pin_any_item.jpg" width="340" /><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5382578/pin-any-item-to-the-windows-7-taskbar">Pin Any Item to the Windows 7 Taskbar</a>: <em>We already showed you how to pin specific folders, and this is just a slightly tweaked application of that method.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5249512/put-a-recycle-bin-shortcut-on-the-windows-7-taskbar">Put a Recycle Bin Shortcut on the Windows 7 Taskbar</a>: <em>Once you are finished, you&#39;ll have a separate recycle icon on the taskbarâ€”useful for quick access to deleted files without having to hunt down an icon on your desktop.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5360607/get-a-functional-recycle-bin-on-windows-7s-taskbar">Get a Functional Recycle Bin on Windows 7's Taskbar</a>: <em>TechSpot&#39;s solutionâ€”creating a Quick Launch taskbar, removing its text and title, then bringing the desktop Recycle Bin icon into itâ€”covers all the bases, and lets you place your Recycle Bin pretty much wherever you&#39;d like on the taskbar.</em></li> </ul> <h3 style="font-size: 120%; margin-top: 20px;">Jump lists</h3> <ul> <li style=""><img src="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/lifehacker/2009/10/jump_list_leftclick.jpg" width="340" /></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5364198/master-windows-7-jump-lists-to-boost-your-win7-productivity">Master Windows 7 Jump Lists to Boost Your Win7 Productivity</a>: <em>For those of you that haven't yet tried out Windows 7, when you right-click on a taskbar button in Windows 7, a menu slides out with recent documents and application tasks. Here's a rundown of our favorite Jump List boosters.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5264808/winfox-adds-jump-lists-to-firefox-on-windows-7">Winfox Adds Jump Lists to Firefox on Windows 7</a>: <em>Jump Lists are one of the best new features in Windows 7, and since Firefox still doesn't take advantage of them, a small utility called Winfox adds the feature for you.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5361018/win7shell-adds-windows-7-jump-list-support-to-winamp">Win7shell Adds Windows 7 Jump List Support to Winamp</a>: <em>Once you've downloaded, installed the plugin, and pinned Winamp to the taskbar, the Jump List should immediately start tracking your recently played media files.</em></li> </ul> <h3 style="font-size: 120%; margin-top: 20px;">Built-in Applications</h3> <ul> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5245396/set-up-and-use-xp-mode-in-windows-7">Set Up and Use XP Mode in Windows 7</a>: <em>Windows 7&#39;s new XP Mode lets you seamlessly run virtualized applications alongside your regular Windows 7 applicationsâ€”so your outdated software will continue to work.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5078756/windows-7s-calculator-bundles-real+life-uses">Calculator</a>: <em>While mathletes, scientists, coders, and statisticians will appreciate Windows 7's built-in calculator's programmer, statistics, and scientific modes, everyday people will love figuring out things like hourly wages and mortgage payments without a spreadsheet</em>.</li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5082266/powershell-comes-with-windows-7">PowerShell</a>: <em>(A) souped-up command line and scripting GUI that frees you, finally, from the limits of DOS batch scripts.</em></li> <li> <embed name="viddler" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowfullscreen="true" src="http://www.viddler.com/player/e9310308/" allowscriptaccess="never" height="303" wmode="transparent" width="437"></embed><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5132348/windows-7-media-centers-music-player-is-hot-hot-hot">Windows 7 Media Center's Music Player Is Hot Hot Hot</a>: <em>Good news for music lovers excited for Windows 7: The new and improved music interface in Windows 7 Media Center is overflowing with eye candy and usability.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5135289/windows-7s-wordpad-opens-word-2007-docx-files">Windows 7's WordPad Opens Word 2007 DOCX Files</a>: <em>... The ribbon-style WordPad in Windows 2007 opens Word 2007 files, the .docx kind, pretty handily, albeit with some formatting loss.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5144757/first-look-at-windows-7s-backup-and-restore-center">Backup and Restore Center</a>: <em>For the average user with both media and crucial file needs, Windows 7's default backup features look promising.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5176876/windows-7-guest-mode-creates-bomb+proof-accounts">Windows 7 Guest Mode Creates Bomb-Proof Accounts</a>: <em>In the simplest terms, Guest Mode takes a snapshot of how a PC was working before the kid, friend, coffeeshop customer, or whoever else is using the Guest Mode account logs on. That user can't do much to alter the system, and whatever they can do, like dropping files on the desktop, is discarded when they log off.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5197051/windows-7-calibration-and-cleartype-tools-fine+tune-your-displays/gallery/">Windows 7 Calibration and ClearType Tools Fine-Tune Your Displays</a>: <em>Windows 7's color calibration and ClearType tools might be good enough for non-graphic-designers to stick with.</em></li> </ul> <h3 style="font-size: 120%; margin-top: 20px;">Themes, wallpapers, and login screens</h3> <ul> <li><img src="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/lifehacker/2009/10/win7_themes.jpg" width="340" /><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5131371/windows-7-betas-many-free-and-legit-themes">Windows 7 Beta's Many Free and Legit Themes</a>: <em>Microsoft is offering 20 fresh themes (in Windows 7). Here's a closer look.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5187312/grab-every-regions-windows-7-wallpapers-in-one-download">Grab Every Region's Windows 7 Wallpapers in One Download</a>: <em>Microsoft allowed Windows Vista Magazine to bundle up every wallpaper from Windows 7's regional releases and, boy, we're glad they did. One file brings a lot of new looks to any desktop, Windows 7 or otherwise.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5291544/secret-registry-hack-customizes-windows-7-logon-button-set">Secret Registry Hack Customizes Windows 7 Logon "Button Set"</a>: <em>Rafael Rivera, the same expert Windows hacker that figured out how to customize your Windows 7 logon background, finds another hack that changes the UI to look better with darker background images.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5387563/microsoft-releases-more-free-windows-7-theme-downloads">Microsoft Releases More Free Windows 7 Theme Downloads</a>: <em>The full-fledged themes are specific downloads for Windows 7 users, but anyone can grab the wallpapers from Windows 7's Personalization Gallery for their system.</em></li> </ul> <h3 style="font-size: 120%; margin-top: 20px;">Mouse and Keyboard Shortcuts</h3> <ul> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5132073/the-best-new-windows-7-keyboard-shortcuts">The Best New Windows 7 Keyboard Shortcuts</a>: <em>Windows 7 has more cool new shortcuts than you can shake a stick at.</em></li> <li> <embed type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowfullscreen="true" src="http://www.flickr.com/apps/video/stewart.swf?v=71377" allowscriptaccess="never" flashvars="intl_lang=en-us&amp;photo_secret=cbd5644492&amp;photo_id=3005356495&amp;hd_default=false" height="213" wmode="transparent" width="340"></embed><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5077379/new-aero-shake-clears-the-windows-7-desktop">Aero Shake</a>: <em>When you want to focus on the task at hand on a desktop cluttered with windows, just grab the window bar of the app you want to work in and shake it back and forth to clear away the rest. Another shake will restore the background apps to their former state. You can also drag and drop a window to the edge of the screen to maximize it, and click on its top bar again to restore its previous size.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5077728/snap-any-window-to-half-the-screen-size-in-windows-7">Snap windows to half screen size</a>: <em>... Dragging a window to the top of the screen maximizes it. Following that, if you drag a window all the way to the left or the right of the screen, Windows 7 will display a glass overlay on the desktop. Let go of the mouse button and it will snap the window onto that overlay, which is half the screen&#39;s sizeâ€”a handy helper for widescreen monitor owners.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5283027/maximize-windows-vertically-with-a-double+click-in-windows-7">Maximize Windows Vertically with a Double-Click in Windows 7</a>: <em>Reader John points out that you can simply move your mouse to the top of a window until the pointer switches to the resize icon, and then double-click your mouse to instantly maximize the window to fill all the available vertical space.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5140896/shift-and-right+click-to-expand-windows-7s-send-to-menu">Shift and Right-Click to Expand Windows 7's Send To Menu</a>: <em>Just as with Vista, holding down the Shift key while right-clicking in Windows 7 gives you a fuller range of options.</em></li> <li><img src="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/lifehacker/2009/10/jump_list_leftclick.jpg" width="340" /><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5302642/activate-windows-7-jumplists-with-the-left-mouse-button">Activate Windows 7 Jumplists with the Left Mouse Button</a>: <em>You don&#39;t have to right-click on the taskbar buttons to activate Windows 7&#39;s Jumplistsâ€”you can hold the left mouse button and drag upwards.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5294468/windows-7-creates-new-folders-with-a-hotkey">Windows 7 Creates New Folders With a Hotkey</a>: To create a new folder, simply press Ctrl+Shift+N with an explorer window open and the folder will instantly show up, ready to be renamed to something more useful.</li> </ul> <h3 style="font-size: 120%; margin-top: 20px;">Tweaks, fixes, and customizations</h3> <ul> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5384603/the-best-windows-tweaks-that-still-work-in-windows-7">The Best Windows Tweaks that Still Work in Windows 7</a>: <em>The final version of Windows 7 is being released this week to the general public, and after you get your hands on it the first thing you'll need to know is: Do all my tweaks still work?</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5221303/customize-or-disable-windows-7s-action-center">Customize or Disable Windows 7's Action Center</a>: <em>Windows 7's Action Center does a great job of compressing all of Windows' update/alert/whatever notifications into one icon, but it takes some tweaking to make it show what you want, or disable it entirely.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5130368/add-text-to-the-windows-7-taskbar-buttons">Add text to the Windows 7 taskbar buttons</a>: <em>Just right-click the taskbar, select Properties, then change the Taskbar buttons drop-down from "Always combine, hide labels" to "Never combine."</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5262909/set-default-printers-based-on-network-in-windows-7">Set Default Printers Based on Network in Windows 7</a>: <em>Windows 7 sports a great new feature that allows you to set default printers based on what network your computer is connected to, perfect for folks who carry laptops from network to network.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5372280/get-quick-access-to-windows-7s-jump-lists-from-the-keyboard">Get Quick Access to Windows 7's Jump Lists From the Keyboard</a>: <em>When we showed you how to master Windows 7's new Jump Lists feature, there was one extremely useful tip that we left out: you can also access them from your keyboard.</em></li> <li><img src="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/lifehacker/2009/10/custom_theme.jpg" width="340" /><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5278966/create-and-share-custom-themes-in-windows-7">Create and Share Custom Themes in Windows 7</a>: <em>Microsoft's Engineering Windows 7 weblog details how to create, save, and share your own custom Windows 7 themes, complete with wallpaper, window color, and sounds.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5131803/get-the-old-show-desktop-back-in-windows-7++kinda">Get the Old &quot;Show Desktop&quot; Back in Windows 7â€”Kinda</a>: <em>The short version: Create a folder, place a "Show Desktop.scf" file in there (either your standard Google-found kind or the script available at the bottom link), then right-click your taskbar to create a "New Toolbar" that points to that folder. Turn off the text and titles on that new toolbar, change the icons to large size, and then put your new one-button toolbar where you'd like.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5260396/hidden-windows-7-tool-troubleshoots-sleep-mode-problems">Hidden Windows 7 Tool Troubleshoots Sleep Mode Problems</a>: <em>The report lists all of the devices that are causing problems with sleep mode, explains the different power saving modes your computer supports, and even gives you detailed information on your batteryâ€”invaluable information when your system takes forever to go in and out of sleep mode.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5354879/disable-the-new-libraries-feature-on-windows-7">Disable the New Libraries Feature on Windows 7</a>: <em>Simply download, extract, and double-click on the provided registry hack file, then restart your computer and you'll see that the Libraries are completely gone. There's also an uninstall registry script provided just in case.</em></li> </ul> <h3 style="font-size: 120%; margin-top: 20px;">Third-party helpers</h3> <ul> <li><img src="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/lifehacker/2009/10/logon_changer.jpg" width="340" /><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5182061/logon-changer-customizes-the-windows-7-login-screen">Logon Changer Customizes the Windows 7 Login Screen</a>: <em>Tiny system customizing utility Logon Changer for Windows 7 swaps out the logon screen wallpaper easily. Using the utility is simpleâ€”just select a new wallpaper, test it, and you are done.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5238960/xdn-tweaker-updates-to-tweak-windows-7/gallery/">Xdn Tweaker Updates to Tweak Windows 7</a>: <em>If you want your system to remember or not remember how you sort certain folders, edit what's accessible through the right-click menu, or de-hook Windows Media Player from all the files it tries to glom onto, Xdn does those things for Windows 7.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5251056/glass-cmd-enables-aero-transparency-for-the-command-prompt">Glass CMD Enables Aero Transparency for the Command Prompt</a>: <em>Glass CMD for Vista forces command prompt windows to use Aero's glass transparency effect.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5274325/gmail-notifier-plus-adds-email-alerts-to-the-windows-7-taskbar">Gmail Notifier Plus Adds Email Alerts to the Windows 7 Taskbar</a>: <em>Gmail Notifier Plus displays your unread email count right in the Windows 7 taskbar, including popup message previews and Jump Lists integration.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5287092/switch-power-management-plans-with-a-hotkey">Switch Power Management Plans With a Hotkey</a>: <em>Once you&#39;ve created the shortcut, you can assign a hotkey in the properties dialogâ€”even better, put the shortcut in a location to be indexed by Launchy or the Vista start menu search, or even add it to your AutoHotkey automation script.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5303510/csmenu-brings-the-classic-start-menu-back-to-windows-7">CSMenu Brings the Classic Start Menu Back to Windows 7</a>: <em>Application launcher CSMenu makes up for the lack of a classic start menu option in Windows 7 by creating a menu that looks and works just like the ancient Windows 2000 menu did.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5313116/ultimate-windows-tweaker-updates-improves-windows-7-support">Ultimate Windows Tweaker Updates, Improves Windows 7 Support</a>: <em>Ultimate Windows Tweaker adds new features to an already excellent tool for tweaking all of the hidden Windows settings you normally can't access.</em></li> <li><img src="http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/lifehacker/2009/10/tab_switcher.jpg" width="340" /><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5382006/vistaswitcher-is-an-absolutely-awesome-alt+tab-replacement">VistaSwitcher is an Absolutely Awesome Alt-Tab Replacement</a>: <em>It's a little difficult to showcase how well this thing works with just a screenshot, but you can see the partially transparent Alt-Tab switcher window, complete with a massive preview window and the window titles easily readable.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5384714/windows-7-recovery-discs-gets-your-system-out-of-tight-spots">Windows 7 Recovery Discs Gets Your System Out of Tight Spots</a>: <em>Boot your system from NeoSmart's CD, and you'll get a stripped-down Windows system with a window offering startup file repair, Restore Point returns, recovery from a whole-cloth image, memory testing, and a command prompt for those dire moments when only frantically Google-d terminal instructions can save you.</em></li> <li><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5383474/hulu-desktop-integration-brings-hulu-to-windows-7-media-center">Hulu Desktop Integration Brings Hulu to Windows 7 Media Center</a>: <em>Free application Hulu Desktop Integration brings Hulu's remote-friendly desktop app to your Windows Media Center.</em></li> </ul> <hr /> We hope you found at least one link in that rather large list that helps you get settled into your new OS. Did we miss anything? Got a favorite tip or link you feel Windows 7 newcomers should consider? Share it in the comments. <p />  <a href="http://ads.pheedo.com/click.phdo?s=03b5be32465f5a7e7ef611844a27d384&amp;p=1"><img src="http://ads.pheedo.com/img.phdo?s=03b5be32465f5a7e7ef611844a27d384&amp;p=1" border="0" alt="" style="border: 0;" /></a> <img src="http://a.rfihub.com/eus.gif?eui=2225" border="0" height="0" alt="" width="0" /><p><iframe src="http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/rakd0gtdk7723gpnhframh3eso/300/250?ca=1&amp;fh=280#http%3A%2F%2Flifehacker.com%2F5386953%2Flifehackers-complete-guide-to-windows-7" marginwidth="0" frameborder="0" height="280" marginheight="0" scrolling="no" width="100%"></iframe></p><div> <a href="http://feeds.gawker.com/~ff/lifehacker/full?a=nhQwwDGgttY:XvDLjXtN3rc:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/lifehacker/full?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0" /></a> <a href="http://feeds.gawker.com/~ff/lifehacker/full?a=nhQwwDGgttY:XvDLjXtN3rc:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/lifehacker/full?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0" /></a> <a href="http://feeds.gawker.com/~ff/lifehacker/full?a=nhQwwDGgttY:XvDLjXtN3rc:D7DqB2pKExk"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/lifehacker/full?i=nhQwwDGgttY:XvDLjXtN3rc:D7DqB2pKExk" border="0" /></a> <a href="http://feeds.gawker.com/~ff/lifehacker/full?a=nhQwwDGgttY:XvDLjXtN3rc:V_sGLiPBpWU"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/lifehacker/full?i=nhQwwDGgttY:XvDLjXtN3rc:V_sGLiPBpWU" border="0" /></a> </div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/lifehacker/full/~4/nhQwwDGgttY" height="1" width="1" /></div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/lifehackers-complete-guide-to-windows-7-windo-0">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

<title>Western Digital Caviar Black 2TB</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/western-digital-caviar-black-2tb/</link>
<pubDate>Fri, 23 Oct 2009 20:06:40 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/10/western-digital-caviar-black-2tb/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[  <div style="font-family: sans-serif; overflow: auto; margin: 0px 10px;"><h2 style="margin: 0.25em 0 0 0;" /><div class=""><a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/article/reviews/western_digital_caviar_black_2tb">Western Digital Caviar Black 2TB</a></div></h2> <div style="margin-bottom: 0.5em;">via <a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/articles/all" class="f">Maximum PC all RSS Feed</a> by Nathan Edwards on 10/22/09</div><br style="display: none;" /> <h3>Faster than a VelociRaptor, and six times the capacity <br /></h3> <p>After months of making do with 5,400rpm and 5,900rpm 2TB drives and odd-bird 1.5TB drives, itâ€™s finally happening: 7,200rpm two-terabyte hard drives are coming to rigs near you. First out of the gate and into our greedy arms is Western Digitalâ€™s 2TB Caviar Black, the performance cousin to <a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/article/reviews/western_digital_caviar_green_2tb?OTC-U4P481274081">the 2TB Caviar Green we reviewed in May</a>. And brother, itâ€™s just what weâ€™ve been waiting for.</p> <p>The 2TB Caviar Black is specâ€™d to impress, with four 500GB platters, two processors, 64MB of cache, and a dual-stage actuator system that puts a fine-tuned piezoelectric actuator head at the end of the standard magnetic actuator, enabling fine-tuned tracking for speedy seek times. The Caviar Black also comes with WDâ€™s standard No-Touch ramp loader, so the read/write head never comes in contact with the platters, increasing the driveâ€™s lifespan.</p> <div style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/files/u90693/wdc_full.jpg"><img src="http://www.maximumpc.com/files/u90693/wdc_405.jpg" height="280" width="405" /></a><br /><strong>If this is the shape of 7,200rpm drives to come, we're wetting ourselves with excitement.</strong></div> <p>All these little extras add up, and the 2TB Caviar Black offers the speediest sustained reads and writesâ€”exceeding 112MB/s eachâ€”of any consumer magnetic hard drive weâ€™ve ever tested. Thatâ€™s 15 percent faster than the Seagate Barracuda 7200.11 1.5TBâ€™s read speeds. The 1.5TB Barracuda, previously our high-capacity speed champion, couldnâ€™t keep up in sustained writes, eitherâ€”here the Caviar was nearly 30 percent faster. And thanks to the greater areal density of the Caviar drive, its random-access read and write times are just 7.6ms and 5.0ms, respectively. You wonâ€™t find faster seeks short of a VelociRaptor or solid state drive. Of course, solid state drives offer the best performanceâ€”the $370 Patriot Torqx, our Best of the Best SSD, achieves sustained reads of over 200MB/s, sustained writes of over 175MB/s, and seek times measured in the tenths of milliseconds.</p> <p>The 2TB Caviar Black has an MSRP of $300, the same price that low-powered 2TB drives like the Caviar Green and Barracuda LP debuted at earlier this year. Street prices, of course, will be lower, and keep fallingâ€”the first waves of 2TB drives, the â€œgreenâ€ ones, are already selling for as low as $200. And the Caviar Blackâ€™s sustained reads and writes trump the fastest of those green drives by 20MB/s.<br />Â <br />The 1.5TB Barracuda held a spot on our Best of the Best list for more than a year, but now itâ€™s been firmly supplantedâ€”the 2TB Caviar Black is officially our favorite hard drive.</p> <p>Expect 7,200rpm 2TB drives from Hitachi, Seagate, and others in the next few months as well, with the aim of high performance. But if you buy a capacity hard drive today, next week, or even half a year from now, you canâ€™t go wrong with this Caviar Black. It has the fastest sustained read and write speeds of any consumer magnetic hard drive weâ€™ve ever tested. Itâ€™s faster in any benchmark than all standard hard drives save the WD VelociRaptor, which still holds the edge in burst speeds and random-access timesâ€”<em>barely</em>. Think about that for a second: You can get VelociRaptor-busting speed and six-and-a-half times the capacity for $300. Weâ€™re sold.</p></div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/western-digital-caviar-black-2tb">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>

<title>Study: HDDs Headed for the Bargain Bin, Not Obsolescence</title>
<link>http://www.alecksdad.com/study-hdds-headed-for-the-bargain-bin-not-obsolescence/</link>
<pubDate>Mon, 26 Oct 2009 16:48:08 +0000</pubDate>
<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[News]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="news"><![CDATA[News]]></category>

<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.alecksdad.com/2009/10/study-hdds-headed-for-the-bargain-bin-not-obsolescence/</guid>
<description></description>
<content:encoded><![CDATA[  <div style="font-family: sans-serif; overflow: auto; margin: 0px 10px;"><h2 style="margin: 0.25em 0 0 0;" /><div class=""><a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/article/news/study_hdds_headed_bargain_bin_not_obsolescence">Study: HDDs Headed for the Bargain Bin, Not Obsolescence</a></div></h2> <div style="margin-bottom: 0.5em;">via <a href="http://www.maximumpc.com/articles/all" class="f">Maximum PC all RSS Feed</a> by Paul Lilly on 10/26/09</div><br style="display: none;" /> <p>Maybe not next year, or even the year after, but sometime in the not too distant future, mainstream storage duties are destined to make the jump from mechanical hard drives to flash-based SSDs, right? Not <a href="http://www.physorg.com/news175505861.html">according to a new study</a> published in a recent issue of IEEE Transactions on Magnetics. Not only are hard drives in it for the long haul, but the cost to storage ratio will shrink dramatically, the study suggests.</p> <p>Some would argue it already has, but study authors Professor Mark Kryder and PhD student Chang Soo Kim of Carnegie Mellon University predict that by the year 2020, a two-disk, 2.5-inch HDD with 14TB of storage capacity will run a mere $40. And if that weren't enough to keep mechanical storage media relevant into the next decade and beyond, the duo also suggest that flash memory technology will run into technical roadblocks that will halt its continued scaling before 2020.</p> <p>The predictions surprised even the study's authors, who set out to examine 13 up-and-coming nonvolatile memory (NVM) technologies and see if one of them had the potential to leapfrog HDDs on a cost-per-terabyte basis by 2020. </p> <p>&quot;We were surprised to find that the study indicated that, even in 2020, hard drives were likely to be considerably less expensive on a cost per terabyte basis than any of the competing technologies,&quot; Kryder told PhysOrg.com. &quot;It was also somewhat surprising to find that the technical potential of a technology was not necessarily well-correlated with where the industry was investing the most dollars; rather, industrial firms are tending to invest where they have they most know-how. This is not necessarily the wisest decision, but is quite understandable.&quot; </p> <p>Before dismissing the findings as unlikely, it should be noted that Kryder previously served as CTO for Seagate, so he's at least familiar with the storage sector. Nevertheless, do you see HDDs standing in the spotlight for another decade? </p> <p align="center"><img src="http://www.maximumpc.com/files/u69/Hard_Drives.jpg" height="303" width="405" /></p> <p><span style="font-size: xx-small;">Image Credit: simbaint.com </span></p></div>      <p style="font-size: 10px;">  <a href="http://posterous.com">Posted via email</a>   from <a href="http://danielhpavey.posterous.com/study-hdds-headed-for-the-bargain-bin-not-obs">Daniel's posterous</a>  </p>  ]]></content:encoded>
<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

<wp:post_name>study-hdds-headed-for-the-bargain-bin-not-obsolescence</wp:post_name>
